headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Angie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Q4 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you, I would now like to turn the conferen
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Angie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Q4 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you, I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-lookin
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. 
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, February 20, 2015, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Clem. We had a pretty good quarter Q4 and year-end 2014. I want to commend the operations, field support, pricing and real estate groups for doing such a superb job last year and really positioning us well for a solid 2015. And with that, operat
componenttext:
Thanks, Clem. We had a pretty good quarter Q4 and year-end 2014. I want to commend the operations, field support, pricing and real estate groups for doing such a superb job last year and really positioning us well for a solid 2015. 
And with that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about how rent and discount trended in Q4 and year-over-year basis and how that translated into January.
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about how rent and discount trended in Q4 and year-over-year basis and how that translated into January.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. From a discounting standpoint, we increased our discounting during the fourth quarter, which was consistent with what we talked about in the third quarter conference call, where we wanted to ramp up the occupancy spread, and we were goi
componenttext: Yes, this is John. From a discounting standpoint, we increased our discounting during the fourth quarter, which was consistent with what we talked about in the third quarter conference call, where we wanted to ramp up the occupancy spread, and we were going to discount more as well as spend more on television advertising, which we did. And we were able to accomplish a goal of increasing our occupancy. In terms of street rates, rates -- move-in rates, they were both higher in the fourth quarter relative to fourth quarter of last year. On the move-in rate, which is more important than the street rate, move-ins were coming in at about 4% higher. And we got about 4% more move-ins also. So it was a great quarter. We accomplished what we wanted to accomplish, and we're pretty happy with that.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And have those trends held into January pretty well?
componenttext: And have those trends held into January pretty well?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Into January, we did a little bit more television, and move-in volumes kind of flattened out a little bit, but we were increasing street rates more. So we pretty much broke even on the move-ins, but they were moving in at rates that were higher than the 4
componenttext: Into January, we did a little bit more television, and move-in volumes kind of flattened out a little bit, but we were increasing street rates more. So we pretty much broke even on the move-ins, but they were moving in at rates that were higher than the 4%, I would say.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the second question for me on the Shurgard acquisition, the basic math gets you about $250 a foot there, which seems pretty risky. Can just maybe give us a little more color on the assets they bought and if that's market or what was unique about
componenttext: Okay. And the second question for me on the Shurgard acquisition, the basic math gets you about $250 a foot there, which seems pretty risky. Can just maybe give us a little more color on the assets they bought and if that's market or what was unique about those assets to drive the pricing there?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll just say the portfolio is about 69%, 70% occupied. On a trailing NOI basis, the NOI is somewhere between 4% and 5%. And you should know European rental rates on average are about double the U.S.
componenttext: Well, I'll just say the portfolio is about 69%, 70% occupied. On a trailing NOI basis, the NOI is somewhere between 4% and 5%. And you should know European rental rates on average are about double the U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you -- I'm referring to your actually third quarter 10-Q, just given your fourth quarter is not yet. I know in the sector, in most real estate sectors [indiscernible] that definition is a little bit different by company. Yours is obviously a little
componenttext: Could you -- I'm referring to your actually third quarter 10-Q, just given your fourth quarter is not yet. I know in the sector, in most real estate sectors [indiscernible] that definition is a little bit different by company. Yours is obviously a little bit more conservative, given that you wait 3 years for assets to move into your pool. But going back to the third quarter Q, it seems like the property pool from 2013, the things that you bought, the NOI differential in 3Q '14 over 3Q '13 was about $15 million, pretty substantial. And your 2012 pool was up $1.4 million. Now just hypothetically, if you made your definition a little bit more loose and more familiar to other companies in the sector, how would your 6.8% NOI growth, what would that be? Would it be close to 8% or more than that or less than that? Just curious because really trying to look at it on an apples-to-apples basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Ki, I'll touch on that and then I'll let John add. I don't know that I could call our same-store pool more conservative. I would call it more practical because if what we're trying to do is give you the investor as well as our directors and our -- i
componenttext: Well, Ki, I'll touch on that and then I'll let John add. I don't know that I could call our same-store pool more conservative. I would call it more practical because if what we're trying to do is give you the investor as well as our directors and our -- it is the way we run our company as well, what an apples-to-apples comparison of the business in terms of our store performance by properties. And we're not trying to manage to a number or put in properties that clearly are not stabilized to improve our same-store NOI. So the numbers that we published for you and put in the 10-K and the 10-Q are the same kind of numbers that we run the business with. And properties that aren't stabilized go into a nonstabilized pool, and the management teams are measured on those differently than they are on the same-store operations. What the numbers are with nonstabilized properties in them is obviously they be higher because the properties are stabilized and so their growth rates are higher. What it is, I don't know. John?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I have nothing to add to that.
componenttext: No, I have nothing to add to that.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a second question. If I look at your New York revenue growth over the -- and not just your New York assets but for most of the public peers and whistle stores in New York. It doesn't seem like from a same-store revenue standpoint, it's real
componenttext: Okay. And just a second question. If I look at your New York revenue growth over the -- and not just your New York assets but for most of the public peers and whistle stores in New York. It doesn't seem like from a same-store revenue standpoint, it's really growing that much faster than any other market, and even those big bucket you call other markets is pretty close to that or better. So just curious, is a market like New York really, based on pricing, is it really going to put up that much better growth than you think just self-storage in most other markets? Or is it just kind of an 2014 anomaly?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you're referring specifically to New York, we talked about that in the third quarter also where I mentioned that part of the problem we have was a year-over-year comp because we saw a huge lift from Superstorm Sandy, which occurred in the fourth q
componenttext: Yes. If you're referring specifically to New York, we talked about that in the third quarter also where I mentioned that part of the problem we have was a year-over-year comp because we saw a huge lift from Superstorm Sandy, which occurred in the fourth quarter of 2012. And that carried over in throughout 2013 where occupancies were very high in New York and we were experiencing above-average rental rate growth. When we got to 2014, then the comps became very difficult, and so that's what you're seeing if you're looking at Q3, and we show you Q4 in our 10-K, you'll see a similar thing. But what we are seeing now is as the comps now, we're kind of rounding the corner again. New York is beginning to fare better, meaning that the year-over-year growth is going -- is starting to rise and get back on track to what I would say a normal growth would be for it.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ki, if you look across the portfolio in Q4, and you'll see this when the K is out, you're going to see an acceleration on the West Coast market. For example, if you take Portland for the year, it was up 7.4% but in Q4, it was up 8.6%. San Diego for the ye
componenttext: Ki, if you look across the portfolio in Q4, and you'll see this when the K is out, you're going to see an acceleration on the West Coast market. For example, if you take Portland for the year, it was up 7.4% but in Q4, it was up 8.6%. San Diego for the year was up 4.9% but for the fourth quarter up 6.6%. Sacramento for the year, up 4.7% but Q4, 6.6%. Los Angeles for the year, 5.2% but for the quarter, 6.1%. So you've seen the real acceleration in the rate of growth in our West Coast markets and then also in some of the Florida markets, Orlando for the year was 4.4% but in Q4, 5.6%.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Jana Galan of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Jana Galan of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the third quarter call, you mentioned looking at other debt financing options. Curious why you decided on the preferred financing in December and how you're thinking about capital needs in 2015.
componenttext: In the third quarter call, you mentioned looking at other debt financing options. Curious why you decided on the preferred financing in December and how you're thinking about capital needs in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the preferred financing in Q4, we thought the 5.80% or 5.87% was a pretty attractive rate. It wasn't a big trade but it was -- and it was a nice trade below a 6% coupon. Regarding the debt financing, we're still looking at various options [indiscern
componenttext: Well, the preferred financing in Q4, we thought the 5.80% or 5.87% was a pretty attractive rate. It wasn't a big trade but it was -- and it was a nice trade below a 6% coupon. Regarding the debt financing, we're still looking at various options [indiscernible] anything to add to that John.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think right now, we're not under pressure to do anything even though our development pipeline is ramping up as we've noted in the press release. But for the most part, the ramp-up and development can be funded with our routine cash flows. So the big
componenttext: No. I think right now, we're not under pressure to do anything even though our development pipeline is ramping up as we've noted in the press release. But for the most part, the ramp-up and development can be funded with our routine cash flows. So the big question mark for us is the acquisition environment and how that plays out for the rest of the year. Currently, we're sitting on about $150 million to $180 million of cash. Most of that is from that preferred that we issued in December. But as Ron said, we are looking at issuing -- potentially issuing debt. So -- but that's not something that we feel under pressure to be doing anytime soon.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick question on advertising. If you can kind of comment on paid search trends where you think pricing will increase in '15 and maybe the decision to continue doing TV advertising.
componenttext: And then just a quick question on advertising. If you can kind of comment on paid search trends where you think pricing will increase in '15 and maybe the decision to continue doing TV advertising.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did -- as we mentioned, we did television in Q4. We did some in January. We continue to evaluate the effectiveness of television advertising. My gut is that we will probably do similar amounts as we did in 2014 but that kind of remains to be seen.
componenttext: Yes, we did -- as we mentioned, we did television in Q4. We did some in January. We continue to evaluate the effectiveness of television advertising. My gut is that we will probably do similar amounts as we did in 2014 but that kind of remains to be seen. Our occupancies are so high right now. It gets more and more difficult to justify spending television advertising dollars. With respect to other advertising, we continue to spend money on search terms with both Google and Yahoo!. And I expect that to continue probably at the same pace as we have experienced in 2014.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Smedes Rose with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Smedes Rose with Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you just about your -- the payroll. I know you've talked earlier in the year about producing hours, and you -- it did decline again in the fourth quarter and, of course, for the year. Just with -- are you seeing any pressure at that segmen
componenttext: I wanted to ask you just about your -- the payroll. I know you've talked earlier in the year about producing hours, and you -- it did decline again in the fourth quarter and, of course, for the year. Just with -- are you seeing any pressure at that segment of the labor market and any thoughts on where pricing might go in 2015?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we've done some things to improve labor productivity in the course of 2014. And I would anticipate probably a little more normalized rate of increase in wages between 1% and 2% in 2015 year-over-year. And I say that not knowing the impact that Wal
componenttext: I think we've done some things to improve labor productivity in the course of 2014. And I would anticipate probably a little more normalized rate of increase in wages between 1% and 2% in 2015 year-over-year. And I say that not knowing the impact that Walmart's decision to increase their wage rates is going to have in terms of our ability to recruit people. So that was just announced and I don't know what impact that's going to have, because we usually -- we're kind of in that labor market or way trade zone for our people that we hire as relief managers. So hard to anticipate the impact of that right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the Shurgard expenses, was that -- it looked like they went up a lot in the fourth quarter. Is that just does transaction-oriented or a related [indiscernible] sort of stabilize going forward?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the Shurgard expenses, was that -- it looked like they went up a lot in the fourth quarter. Is that just does transaction-oriented or a related [indiscernible] sort of stabilize going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are you talking about the same-store operating expenses that were up quite a bit?
componenttext: Are you talking about the same-store operating expenses that were up quite a bit?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was -- we had some credits in the fourth quarter of last year that we didn't have in the fourth quarter this year. And then they accelerated some R&M and some -- yes, the credits remain related to property taxes. So they look higher but I think
componenttext: Yes, that was -- we had some credits in the fourth quarter of last year that we didn't have in the fourth quarter this year. And then they accelerated some R&M and some -- yes, the credits remain related to property taxes. So they look higher but I think if you look at the full year, they're a pretty good expense control for the full year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the Shurgard Europe acquisition. I was wondering, Ron, maybe can you frame up what the investment opportunity set for Shurgard Europe looks like and what the pipeline looks like and maybe what the current thinking is towards investmen
componenttext: Just following up on the Shurgard Europe acquisition. I was wondering, Ron, maybe can you frame up what the investment opportunity set for Shurgard Europe looks like and what the pipeline looks like and maybe what the current thinking is towards investments here.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Todd. As you probably know, 2014, the investments we made combined around $90 million, $95 million are the first investments we made in quite sometime in Shurgard. We've really been focusing on taking the cash flow and deleveraging the entity. With t
componenttext: Yes, Todd. As you probably know, 2014, the investments we made combined around $90 million, $95 million are the first investments we made in quite sometime in Shurgard. We've really been focusing on taking the cash flow and deleveraging the entity. With the completion of the private placement in June of last year, refinancing of the debt, Shurgard has a fair amount of free cash flow. And so they've been ramping up their opportunity set in terms of acquisitions and development. And so at year end, I think we have 3 or 4 properties in the pipeline to develop in London. And then we did this acquisition in Germany. And I would anticipate that you'll see more activity out of Shurgard in 2015. We generally don't comment on transactions. They've got some stuff in so I don't want to really get into what the details are. But I would anticipate that Shurgard will be active again in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, on the developments, domestic developments, you're starting to deliver that product in the market now. And I was wondering if you could just give us an update, any thoughts on sort of the lease-up time frames here. I know historical
componenttext: Okay. And then second, on the developments, domestic developments, you're starting to deliver that product in the market now. And I was wondering if you could just give us an update, any thoughts on sort of the lease-up time frames here. I know historically, I believe it would take anywhere from maybe 3 or 4 years or so to lease up the stabilize underdevelopment. I know your large Bronx facility leased up much quicker than that. Just curious what you think the average time to get these projects delivered over the next 12 months to stabilization might look like.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our underwriting of to achieve stabilization has not changed. It's generally somewhere between 3 and 4 years, depending on the property size. And that achievement of stabilization, part of our underwriting is we impute a cost to carry until we do ach
componenttext: Yes. Our underwriting of to achieve stabilization has not changed. It's generally somewhere between 3 and 4 years, depending on the property size. And that achievement of stabilization, part of our underwriting is we impute a cost to carry until we do achieve stabilized NOI. So far, we've been fortunate. I believe most, if not all, of our developments are ahead of schedule in terms of pro forma occupancies and cash flow. They're not ahead of schedule in terms of achieving targeted rents, and that's by design in terms of we use a different pricing strategy for developments than we do for stabilized properties. The Bronx [indiscernible] property is actually about 92% occupied today, which if you would ask me 18 months ago when it opened if we'd be at 92% occupied and 18 months with 4,000 units, I would have laughed. So the pricing group, the marketing groups, we've done a great job in operations in getting that property filled up. And that's kind of the way it's working across the platform. So hopefully, we'll be delivering pleasant surprises with respect to our developments but underwriting hasn't changed.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to see if I can get the occupancy for the end of January.
componenttext: Just want to see if I can get the occupancy for the end of January.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: George, it's about -- let's see, occupancy is about 93% versus 92.3% last year.
componenttext: George, it's about -- let's see, occupancy is about 93% versus 92.3% last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then also just wondering if you can comment on the potential FX impacts from the Shurgard portfolio, just sort of how you're addressing that for 2015.
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then also just wondering if you can comment on the potential FX impacts from the Shurgard portfolio, just sort of how you're addressing that for 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, with respect to the foreign currency exchange?
componenttext: I'm sorry, with respect to the foreign currency exchange?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's not a lot we can do about the dollar strengthening against the euro, if that's what you're referring to. It's certainly going to have a negative effect on Public Storage, given that I think for all of 2014, I think the average exchange rate
componenttext: Well, there's not a lot we can do about the dollar strengthening against the euro, if that's what you're referring to. It's certainly going to have a negative effect on Public Storage, given that I think for all of 2014, I think the average exchange rate was somewhere about 1.32 [ph] whereas the euro, I think that exchange rate today is somewhere down about 1.54 [ph] So there's about a 13%, 15% decline there, meaning all the things being equal, the income we picked up from Shurgard Europe will go down. Keep in mind, however, that Shurgard Europe represents about 5% of our FFO or so. So it's not a significant effect on the overall Public Storage earnings potential.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were fortunate that our intercompany refinanced just about 1 month before the precipitous decline in the euro because that would have been a real hit.
componenttext: We were fortunate that our intercompany refinanced just about 1 month before the precipitous decline in the euro because that would have been a real hit.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you also comment on rental rates in Europe, given there's -- you're still seeing year-over-year declines in the Shurgard portfolio?
componenttext: Okay. And then can you also comment on rental rates in Europe, given there's -- you're still seeing year-over-year declines in the Shurgard portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mean what is the outlook for rental rates in Europe?
componenttext: You mean what is the outlook for rental rates in Europe?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- in Europe, we've gotten really aggressive on pricing to drive occupancy, and we've been able to do that. I think we're up 500, 600 basis points year-over-year in occupancy. But the net effect of both of those is that we've still been able to d
componenttext: Yes. The -- in Europe, we've gotten really aggressive on pricing to drive occupancy, and we've been able to do that. I think we're up 500, 600 basis points year-over-year in occupancy. But the net effect of both of those is that we've still been able to deliver a positive revenue per available foot growth. So while the rates have gone down, the volume has increased greater so revenue growth is positive. I would expect that to continue in 2015 because our average for the year 2014 was about 86%. And Mark and the team over there are targeting to get their portfolio up to 90%, 91%. So I think you'll see probably continued in-place rent movement down, offset by higher volume. And I think we'll see some pretty good top line revenue growth, net-net, out of Shurgard in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about Europe being more active seemingly in the acquisition side. Looking at the press release, they talked about a new EUR 40 million credit facility. Was that meant to be a one-off facility for the acquisitions or is that something that can b
componenttext: You talked about Europe being more active seemingly in the acquisition side. Looking at the press release, they talked about a new EUR 40 million credit facility. Was that meant to be a one-off facility for the acquisitions or is that something that can be expanded and fund anything that's on your plate going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: The EUR 40 million is a revolver, Mike, so it'll -- it has a term of about 3.5 years. So yes, they're putting it in place to help fund the acquisition. But to the extent they do pay it down between now when the facility expires, they can redraw on the lin
componenttext: The EUR 40 million is a revolver, Mike, so it'll -- it has a term of about 3.5 years. So yes, they're putting it in place to help fund the acquisition. But to the extent they do pay it down between now when the facility expires, they can redraw on the line on that revolver.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, just your question might lead to what is the financing capacity of Shurgard. And under their loan, the private placement that they did in June, I think they have borrowing capacity of another EUR 100 million, EUR 150 million.
componenttext: Mike, just your question might lead to what is the financing capacity of Shurgard. And under their loan, the private placement that they did in June, I think they have borrowing capacity of another EUR 100 million, EUR 150 million.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Michael Salinsky with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Michael Salinsky with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just given the high occupancy kind of going into the year here as well as it sounds like the keeping advertising cost the same, just kind of talk about where you see the greatest opportunities on the leasing front 2015, whether maybe you plan to push rate
componenttext: Just given the high occupancy kind of going into the year here as well as it sounds like the keeping advertising cost the same, just kind of talk about where you see the greatest opportunities on the leasing front 2015, whether maybe you plan to push rate a bit more just given the high occupancy? How much concessions you left to reduce? Can you just kind of talk about that a little bit?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'll start and I'll let John add to this. If you look at Q4, we were able to do what I think are 2 really incredible things. We were able to move period and occupancy up 0.8%, which is a real achievement in the fourth quarter as well as move in-plac
componenttext: Mike, I'll start and I'll let John add to this. If you look at Q4, we were able to do what I think are 2 really incredible things. We were able to move period and occupancy up 0.8%, which is a real achievement in the fourth quarter as well as move in-place rents up from 4.6% to 4.9%. So moving in-place rent as well as occupancy in Q4 really set us up nicely for January. And if you go back to what we've been talking about, our opportunities on occupancy are really in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter. So what we did on the promotional discounts in the television in Q4 not only helped our position -- our revenue growth in Q4 which accelerated over Q3, but it's positioned us nicely going into Q3 for higher occupancies -- our Q1, excuse me, for higher occupancies and higher in-place rents.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I would add to that, I think that street rates are going to be higher this year. I think we're seeing competition pushing street rates more aggressively than they have in the past, probably due to the fact that their occupancies are much higher than t
componenttext: And I would add to that, I think that street rates are going to be higher this year. I think we're seeing competition pushing street rates more aggressively than they have in the past, probably due to the fact that their occupancies are much higher than they've experienced before, which overall is a good thing for Public Storage because that's been one of our more difficult places to grow revenue. So as I mentioned, we're seeing move-in rates starting to accelerate. Hopefully, that will continue. I would also think that the level of discounting will subside, will come down. In Q4, we gave away approximately $20 million of discounts. On an annual basis, that's about $80 million. So there's a lot of room to reduce discounting. So we'll work on that also.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: The third bucket, Mike, just to add to that, is customers greater than 1 year upticked in Q4 as well to 56.7% versus 55.8%. So we end the year with about 10,000-plus more customers in that age cohort of greater than 1 year.
componenttext: The third bucket, Mike, just to add to that, is customers greater than 1 year upticked in Q4 as well to 56.7% versus 55.8%. So we end the year with about 10,000-plus more customers in that age cohort of greater than 1 year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then just my follow-up question, you talked about Europe and the acquisition opportunities seeing there. Can you talk a little bit about the U.S. meaning, obviously third quarter, fourth quarter activity seem to pick up there? Are
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then just my follow-up question, you talked about Europe and the acquisition opportunities seeing there. Can you talk a little bit about the U.S. meaning, obviously third quarter, fourth quarter activity seem to pick up there? Are you seeing more product on the market? And then just given the success that you've had on expanding the development pipeline over the last few months, are opportunities becoming more plentiful there?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Q1 is typically a low-product opportunity. There's not a lot of product coming into market in Q1. It really starts to pickup in Q2 and Q3. So there's not a lot of stuff in the market right now in terms of acquisition. As we moved through 2014, I wou
componenttext: Well, Q1 is typically a low-product opportunity. There's not a lot of product coming into market in Q1. It really starts to pickup in Q2 and Q3. So there's not a lot of stuff in the market right now in terms of acquisition. As we moved through 2014, I would tell you pricing continued to get more and more aggressive. We've moved out into some other markets where we have a strong presence, some of the more core competitive market in terms of acquisitions. And I would tell you I mean, there's deals getting done well below 5% cap rates on the acquisition front, which is I'd have to say we somewhat saw this coming a couple of years ago, which is why we've accelerated the development pipeline. If you look at our pipeline, it's almost double what it was at the end of 2013. And I think you'll see us continue to try to accelerate that form of expansion vis-à-vis acquisitions. Very happy with our development pipeline, both the growth of it and the quality of the assets.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have that in front of me. But my gut reaction is probably somewhere about 76% versus, I don't know, a little less than that last year.
componenttext: Yes, I don't have that in front of me. But my gut reaction is probably somewhere about 76% versus, I don't know, a little less than that last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And I know you guys don't typically do this, but just given where your occupancy rates in your commentary regarding street rates, that might be improving in 2015. Just ballpark figure, what do you think your portfolio can handle or push through in terms of street rates in 2015?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015

componenttext: I don't know. I wouldn't want to guess. [indiscernible] being wrong.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dave Bragg with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dave Bragg with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered, but I want to follow up on your point made on acquisition cap rates driving you incrementally into development. To what degree are you seeing that across the rest of the market? How much new supply do you observe u
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered, but I want to follow up on your point made on acquisition cap rates driving you incrementally into development. To what degree are you seeing that across the rest of the market? How much new supply do you observe under construction today relative to 1 year ago?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the simple answer is more. And I'd tell you, it's more than people realized. We had a real estate meeting yesterday and I was surprised at the number of markets where we're starting to see development. So there's a fair amount more activity than peo
componenttext: Well, the simple answer is more. And I'd tell you, it's more than people realized. We had a real estate meeting yesterday and I was surprised at the number of markets where we're starting to see development. So there's a fair amount more activity than people realized. And it's logical, right? If you're a developer and you've got these public companies buying the deals at nice spreads to what you can build it for, why not build a product? And it is coming to market. Texas is an easier market to build in, and so there's a fair amount of product coming online in Dallas and Houston, the Carolinas. So we're going to see more and more development.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is it your sense that the construction environment has loosened up considerably for the private developers?
componenttext: So is it your sense that the construction environment has loosened up considerably for the private developers?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if I look at the per square foot cost, your acquisitions that you did last year, I think it was about $128 a foot. If I look at the cost of your current development pipeline, you're building to about $117 a foot. And I know it's not directly apples-to-
componenttext: So if I look at the per square foot cost, your acquisitions that you did last year, I think it was about $128 a foot. If I look at the cost of your current development pipeline, you're building to about $117 a foot. And I know it's not directly apples-to-apples in terms of the geographic mix. But I guess my question is do you think it's a fair comment to say that you're paying above replacement cost for the acquisition? That's part A.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if that's true, which sounds like it is, why not -- and I know you've accelerated development, but why not put even more capital into the development bucket and pull back on acquisitions?
componenttext: And if that's true, which sounds like it is, why not -- and I know you've accelerated development, but why not put even more capital into the development bucket and pull back on acquisitions?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ross, we are trying. It may -- relative to our size, $400 million may not look like a lot, but that's what we report on is like a pipeline of 29, 30 properties behind that or another 25 or so properties that we're working on to get into the development pi
componenttext: Ross, we are trying. It may -- relative to our size, $400 million may not look like a lot, but that's what we report on is like a pipeline of 29, 30 properties behind that or another 25 or so properties that we're working on to get into the development pipeline. So there's a lot of properties in that mix. We've ramped up the staff considerably. And as we get more and more comfortable in terms of the market, people in place experienced, I think you'll see the development pipeline increase. The great thing about the development pipeline is obviously, we're building the replacement costs. We're building brand new products. We're getting into some markets where there's little competition and where we have little product. So we're really able, with the development teams, to fill in market and some markets that we want to be in and really improve our market share and the quality of our portfolio in the various markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just remind me again, the stabilized yields that you guys are building to based on current market rents is what?
componenttext: And just remind me again, the stabilized yields that you guys are building to based on current market rents is what?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: It varies by property but I'd say somewhere between 8% and 10%.
componenttext: It varies by property but I'd say somewhere between 8% and 10%.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just an extension of that prior questions. If that's true, right, and people are paying pretty low cap rates today, why aren't we about to see, for lack of a better word, an explosion in self-storage construction in the next 12 to 24 months?
componenttext: And just an extension of that prior questions. If that's true, right, and people are paying pretty low cap rates today, why aren't we about to see, for lack of a better word, an explosion in self-storage construction in the next 12 to 24 months?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Ross, it's still hard to do. But as I just touched on with Dave Bragg, there is more development going on and it is accelerating. Think back 2 years ago, no one was really talking about development except us. And now you go to self-storage conferenc
componenttext: Well, Ross, it's still hard to do. But as I just touched on with Dave Bragg, there is more development going on and it is accelerating. Think back 2 years ago, no one was really talking about development except us. And now you go to self-storage conferences and everyone's talking about development and trying to do it. So I believe you will see an acceleration of development. We are seeing it and it will continue to accelerate. And some markets like Austin, there was a portfolio that traded north of $200 a foot, and we're developing in Austin at $80 to $90 a foot. Assume a local guy there could develop at $100, I mean, that's a big spread.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from line of Paula Poskon with D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Your final question comes from line of Paula Poskon with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up a little bit more on the new supply in the amount of development, Ron. Are you seeing that new development in what you would consider to be good in-fill locations? Or are we back to raising the cornfields on -- at the edge of to
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up a little bit more on the new supply in the amount of development, Ron. Are you seeing that new development in what you would consider to be good in-fill locations? Or are we back to raising the cornfields on -- at the edge of town?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't spend a lot of time in the cornfields so I can't tell you about that. In terms of...
componenttext: Well, we don't spend a lot of time in the cornfields so I can't tell you about that. In terms of...

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Metaphorically speaking.
componenttext: Metaphorically speaking.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, no, I know. You're seeing -- where we're seeing the more development in markets where you would expect. The Southeast where it's easier to build and Texas where it's easier to build. So it's logical. Yes, Dave Doll's here in New York. New York,
componenttext: Yes, yes, no, I know. You're seeing -- where we're seeing the more development in markets where you would expect. The Southeast where it's easier to build and Texas where it's easier to build. So it's logical. Yes, Dave Doll's here in New York. New York, we started to see development pick up 18 months ago and a lot of stuff is really coming online in New York. So those are the major markets. And we're doing some stuff that -- we are doing some stuff in California. We don't see other people doing stuff in California. Not a lot in Florida. Give you some idea?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And are you seeing much redevelopment or repurposing? [indiscernible]
componenttext: That's helpful. And are you seeing much redevelopment or repurposing? [indiscernible]

componenttext: Well, we've been doing redevelopment for 5 or 8 years. In terms of what other people are doing, I can't comment. But I mean, that's an ongoing part of our program. So we've been doing it, and we will continue to do that.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Angie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Q4 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you, I would now like to turn the conferen
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Angie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Q4 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you, I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us for our Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than the statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-lo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us for our Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than the statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. 
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, February 20, 2015, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Clem. We had a pretty good quarter Q4 and year end 2014. I want to commend the operations, field support, pricing and real estate groups for doing such a superb job last year and really positioning us well for a solid 2015. And with that, operat
componenttext:
Thanks, Clem. We had a pretty good quarter Q4 and year end 2014. I want to commend the operations, field support, pricing and real estate groups for doing such a superb job last year and really positioning us well for a solid 2015. 
And with that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about how rent and discounting trended in Q4 in a year-over-year basis and how that translated into January.
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about how rent and discounting trended in Q4 in a year-over-year basis and how that translated into January.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. From a discounting standpoint, we increased our discounting during the fourth quarter, which was consistent with what we had talked about in the third quarter conference call, where we wanted to ramp up the occupancy spread, and we were
componenttext: Yes, this is John. From a discounting standpoint, we increased our discounting during the fourth quarter, which was consistent with what we had talked about in the third quarter conference call, where we wanted to ramp up the occupancy spread, and we were going to discount more as well as spend more on television advertising, which we did. And we were able to accomplish a goal of increasing our occupancy. In terms of street rates, and rates -- move-in rates, they were both higher in the fourth quarter relative to fourth quarter of last year. On the move-in rate, which is more important than the street rate, move-ins were coming in at about 4% higher. And we got about 4% more move-ins also. So it was a great quarter. We accomplished what we wanted to accomplish, so we're pretty happy with that.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And have those trends held into January pretty well?
componenttext: And have those trends held into January pretty well?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Into January, we did a little bit more television, and move-in volumes kind of flattened out a little bit, but we were increasing street rates more. So we pretty much broke even on the move-ins, but they were moving in at rates that were higher than the 4
componenttext: Into January, we did a little bit more television, and move-in volumes kind of flattened out a little bit, but we were increasing street rates more. So we pretty much broke even on the move-ins, but they were moving in at rates that were higher than the 4%, I would say.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the second question for me on the Shurgard acquisition, the basic math gets you about $250 a foot there, which seems pretty rich. Can just maybe give us a little more color on the assets they bought and if that's market or what was unique about
componenttext: Okay. And the second question for me on the Shurgard acquisition, the basic math gets you about $250 a foot there, which seems pretty rich. Can just maybe give us a little more color on the assets they bought and if that's market or what was unique about those assets to drive the pricing there?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll just say the portfolio is about 69%, 70% occupied. On a trailing NOI basis, the NOI is somewhere between 4% and 5%. And you should know European rental rates on average are about double the U.S.
componenttext: Well, I'll just say the portfolio is about 69%, 70% occupied. On a trailing NOI basis, the NOI is somewhere between 4% and 5%. And you should know European rental rates on average are about double the U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you -- I'm referring to your, actually, third quarter 10-Q, thus given your fourth quarter is not out yet. But I know in the sector, in most real estate sectors that the same-store NOI definition is a little bit different by company. Yours is obviou
componenttext: Could you -- I'm referring to your, actually, third quarter 10-Q, thus given your fourth quarter is not out yet. But I know in the sector, in most real estate sectors that the same-store NOI definition is a little bit different by company. Yours is obviously a little bit more conservative, given that you wait 3 years for assets to move into your pool. But going back to the third quarter K -- Q, it seems like the property pool from 2013, the things that you bought, the NOI differential in 3Q '14 over 3Q '13 was about $15 million, been a pretty substantial. And your 2012 pool was up $1.4 million. Now just hypothetically, if you made your definition a little bit more loose and more similar to other companies in the sector, how would your 6.8% same-store NOI growth, what would that be? Would it be close to 8% or more than that or less than that? Just curious because really trying to look at is my apples-to-apples basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Ki, I'll touch on that and then I'll let John add. I don't know that whether I could call our same-store pool more conservative. I would call it more practical because if you -- what we're trying to do is give you the investor as well as our directo
componenttext: Well, Ki, I'll touch on that and then I'll let John add. I don't know that whether I could call our same-store pool more conservative. I would call it more practical because if you -- what we're trying to do is give you the investor as well as our directors and our -- this the way we run the company as well, what's an apples-to-apples comparison of the business in terms of our store performance by properties. And we're not trying to manage to a number or put in properties that clearly are not stabilized to improve our same-store NOI. So the numbers that we published for you and put the 10-K and the 10-Q are the same kind of numbers that we run the business with. And properties that aren't stabilized go into a nonstabilized pool, and the management teams are measured on those differently than they are on the same-store operations. What the numbers are with nonstabilized properties in them is obviously they'd be higher because the properties aren't stabilized and so their growth rates are higher. What it is, I don't know. John?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I have nothing to add to that.
componenttext: No, I have nothing to add to that.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a second question. If I look at your New York revenue growth over the -- and not just your New York assets but for most of the public peers and with self-storage in New York. It doesn't seem like from a same-store revenue standpoint, it's r
componenttext: Okay. And just a second question. If I look at your New York revenue growth over the -- and not just your New York assets but for most of the public peers and with self-storage in New York. It doesn't seem like from a same-store revenue standpoint, it's really growing that much faster than any other market, and even those big bucket you call other markets is pretty close to that or better. So just curious, is a market like New York really, based on pricing is it really going to put up that much better growth than you think just self-storage in most other markets? Or is it a kind of 2014 anomaly?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you're referring specifically to New York, we talked about that in the third quarter also where we -- where I mentioned that part of the problem we have was a year-over-year comp because we saw a huge lift from Superstorm Sandy, which occurred in
componenttext: Yes. If you're referring specifically to New York, we talked about that in the third quarter also where we -- where I mentioned that part of the problem we have was a year-over-year comp because we saw a huge lift from Superstorm Sandy, which occurred in the fourth quarter of 2012. And that carried over in throughout 2013 where occupancies were very high in New York and we were experiencing above-average rental rate growth. When we got to 2014, then the comps became very difficult, and so that's what you're seeing and you're -- if you're looking at Q3, in [ph] we show you Q4 in our 10-K, you'll see a similar thing. But what we are seeing now is as the comps now, we're kind of rounding the corner again. New York is beginning to fare better, meaning that the year-over-year growth is going -- is starting to rise and get back on track to what I would say a normal growth would be for it.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ki, if you look across the portfolio in Q4, and you'll see this when the K is out, you're going to see an acceleration on the West Coast market. For example, if you take Portland for the year, it was up 7.4% but in Q4, it was up 8.6%. San Diego for the ye
componenttext: Ki, if you look across the portfolio in Q4, and you'll see this when the K is out, you're going to see an acceleration on the West Coast market. For example, if you take Portland for the year, it was up 7.4% but in Q4, it was up 8.6%. San Diego for the year was up 4.9% but for the fourth quarter up 6.6%. Sacramento for the year, up 4.7% but Q4, 6.6%. Los Angeles for the year, 5.2% but for the quarter, 6.1%. So you've seen the real acceleration in the rate of growth in our West Coast markets and then also in some of the Florida markets, Orlando for the year was 4.4% but in Q4, 5.6%.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the third quarter call, you mentioned looking at other debt financing options. Curious why you decided on the preferred financing in December and how you're thinking about capital needs in 2015.
componenttext: In the third quarter call, you mentioned looking at other debt financing options. Curious why you decided on the preferred financing in December and how you're thinking about capital needs in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, with the preferred financing in Q4, we thought the 5.80 or 5.87 was a pretty attractive rate. It wasn't a big trade but it was -- and it was a nice trade below a 6% coupon. Regarding the debt financing, we're still looking at various options, do you
componenttext: Well, with the preferred financing in Q4, we thought the 5.80 or 5.87 was a pretty attractive rate. It wasn't a big trade but it was -- and it was a nice trade below a 6% coupon. Regarding the debt financing, we're still looking at various options, do you have anything to add on that, John?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think right now, we're not under pressure to do anything even though our development pipeline is ramping up as we've noted in the press release. But for the most part, the ramp-up and development can be funded with our retained cash flows. So the bi
componenttext: No. I think right now, we're not under pressure to do anything even though our development pipeline is ramping up as we've noted in the press release. But for the most part, the ramp-up and development can be funded with our retained cash flows. So the big question mark for us is the acquisition environment and how that plays out for the rest of the year. Currently, we're sitting on about $150 million to $180 million of cash. Most of that is from that preferred that we issued in December. But as Ron said, we are looking at issuing -- potentially issuing debt. So -- but that's not something that we feel under pressure to be doing anytime soon.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick question on advertising. If you can kind of comment on paid search trends where you think pricing will increase in '15 and maybe the decision to continue doing TV advertising.
componenttext: And then just a quick question on advertising. If you can kind of comment on paid search trends where you think pricing will increase in '15 and maybe the decision to continue doing TV advertising.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did. As I mentioned, we did television in Q4. We did some in January. We continue to evaluate the effectiveness of television advertising. My gut is that we will probably do similar amounts as we did in 2014 but that kind of remains to be seen. Ou
componenttext: Yes, we did. As I mentioned, we did television in Q4. We did some in January. We continue to evaluate the effectiveness of television advertising. My gut is that we will probably do similar amounts as we did in 2014 but that kind of remains to be seen. Our occupancies are so high right now. It gets more and more difficult to justify spending television advertising dollars. With respect to other advertising, we continue to spend money on search terms with both Google and Yahoo!. And I expect that to continue probably at the same pace as we have experienced in 2014.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Smedes Rose with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Smedes Rose with Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you just about your -- the payroll. I know you've talked earlier in the year about producing hours, and you -- it did decline again in the fourth quarter and, of course, for the year. Just with -- are you seeing any pressure at that segmen
componenttext: I wanted to ask you just about your -- the payroll. I know you've talked earlier in the year about producing hours, and you -- it did decline again in the fourth quarter and, of course, for the year. Just with -- are you seeing any pressure at that segment of the labor market and any thoughts on where pricing might go in 2015?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Smede, we've done some things to improve labor productivity in the course of 2014. And I would anticipate probably a little more normalized rate of increase in wages between 1% and 2% in 2015 year-over-year. And I say that not knowing the i
componenttext: Well, I think, Smede, we've done some things to improve labor productivity in the course of 2014. And I would anticipate probably a little more normalized rate of increase in wages between 1% and 2% in 2015 year-over-year. And I say that not knowing the impact that Walmart's decision to increase their wage rates is going to have in terms of our ability to recruit people. So that was just announced and I don't know what impact that's going to have, because we usually -- we're kind of in that labor market or way trade zone for our people that we hire as relief managers. So hard to anticipate the impact of that right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the Shurgard expenses, was that -- it looked like they went up a lot in the fourth quarter. Was that just transaction-oriented or a related and without sort of stabilize going forward?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the Shurgard expenses, was that -- it looked like they went up a lot in the fourth quarter. Was that just transaction-oriented or a related and without sort of stabilize going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are you talking about the same-store operating expenses that were up quite a bit?
componenttext: Are you talking about the same-store operating expenses that were up quite a bit?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was -- we had some credits in the fourth quarter of last year that we didn't have in the fourth quarter of this year. And then they accelerated some R&M and some -- yes, the credits were mainly related to property taxes. So they look higher but
componenttext: Yes, that was -- we had some credits in the fourth quarter of last year that we didn't have in the fourth quarter of this year. And then they accelerated some R&M and some -- yes, the credits were mainly related to property taxes. So they look higher but I think if you look at the full year, they're a pretty good expense control for the full year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the Shurgard Europe acquisition. I was wondering, Ron, maybe can you frame up what the investment opportunity set for Shurgard Europe looks like and what the pipeline looks like and maybe what the current thinking is towards investmen
componenttext: Just following up on the Shurgard Europe acquisition. I was wondering, Ron, maybe can you frame up what the investment opportunity set for Shurgard Europe looks like and what the pipeline looks like and maybe what the current thinking is towards investments here.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Todd. As you probably know, 2014, the investments we made combined around $90 million, $95 million are the first investments we made in quite sometime in Shurgard. We've really been focusing on taking the cash flow and deleveraging the entity. With t
componenttext: Yes, Todd. As you probably know, 2014, the investments we made combined around $90 million, $95 million are the first investments we made in quite sometime in Shurgard. We've really been focusing on taking the cash flow and deleveraging the entity. With the completion of the private placement in June of last year, refinancing of the debt, Shurgard has a fair amount of free cash flow. And so they've been ramping up their opportunity set in terms of acquisitions and development. And so at year end, I think we have 3 or 4 properties in the pipeline to develop in London. And then we did this acquisition in Germany. And I would anticipate that you'll see more activity out of Shurgard in 2015. We generally don't comment on transactions. And they've got some stuff in hot pursuit, I don't want to really get into what the details are. But I would anticipate that Shurgard will be active again in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, on the developments, domestic developments, you're starting to deliver that product in the market now. And I was wondering if you could just give us an update, any thoughts on sort of the lease-up time frames here. I know historical
componenttext: Okay. And then second, on the developments, domestic developments, you're starting to deliver that product in the market now. And I was wondering if you could just give us an update, any thoughts on sort of the lease-up time frames here. I know historically, I believe it would take anywhere from maybe 3 or 4 years or so to lease up and stabilize underdevelopment. I know your large Bronx facility leased up much quicker than that. Just curious what you think the average time to get these projects delivered over the next 12 months to stabilization might look like.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our underwriting of -- to achieve stabilization has not changed. It's generally somewhere between 3 and 4 years, depending on the property size. And that achievement of stabilization, part of our underwriting is we impute a cost to carry until we do
componenttext: Yes. Our underwriting of -- to achieve stabilization has not changed. It's generally somewhere between 3 and 4 years, depending on the property size. And that achievement of stabilization, part of our underwriting is we impute a cost to carry until we do achieve stabilized NOI. So far, we've been fortunate. I believe most, if not all, of our developments are ahead of schedule in terms of pro forma occupancies and cash flow. They're not ahead of schedule in terms of achieving targeted rents, and that's by design in terms of we use a different pricing strategy for developments than we do for stabilized properties. The Bronx, the Gerard property is actually about 92% occupied today, which if you would ask me 18 months ago when it opened if we'd be at 92% occupied in 18 months with 4,000 units, I would have laughed. So the pricing group, the marketing groups have done a great job in operations in getting that property filled up. And that's kind of the way it's working across the platform. So hopefully, we'll be delivering pleasant surprises with respect to our developments but our underwriting hasn't changed.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to see if I can get the occupancy for the end of January.
componenttext: Just want to see if I can get the occupancy for the end of January.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: George, it's about -- let's see, occupancy is about 93% versus 92.3% last year.
componenttext: George, it's about -- let's see, occupancy is about 93% versus 92.3% last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then also just wondering if you can comment on the potential FX impacts from the Shurgard portfolio, and sort of how you're addressing that for 2015.
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then also just wondering if you can comment on the potential FX impacts from the Shurgard portfolio, and sort of how you're addressing that for 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, with respect to the foreign currency exchange?
componenttext: I'm sorry, with respect to the foreign currency exchange?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's not a lot we can do about the dollar strengthening against the euro, if that's what you're referring to. It's certainly going to have a negative effect on Public Storage, given that I think for all of 2014, I think the average exchange ratio
componenttext: Well, there's not a lot we can do about the dollar strengthening against the euro, if that's what you're referring to. It's certainly going to have a negative effect on Public Storage, given that I think for all of 2014, I think the average exchange ratio was somewhere about $1.32 whereas the euro, I think that exchange rate today is somewhere down about $1.54. So there's about a 13%, 15% decline there, meaning all the things being equal, the income we picked up from Shurgard Europe will go down. Keep in mind, however, that Shurgard Europe represents about 5% of our FFO or so. So it's not a significant effect on the overall Public Storage earnings potential.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were fortunate that we -- our intercompany loan got refinanced just about 1 month before the precipitous decline in the euro because that would have been a real hit.
componenttext: We were fortunate that we -- our intercompany loan got refinanced just about 1 month before the precipitous decline in the euro because that would have been a real hit.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you also comment on rental rates in Europe, given there's -- you're still seeing year-over-year declines in the Shurgard portfolio?
componenttext: Okay. And then can you also comment on rental rates in Europe, given there's -- you're still seeing year-over-year declines in the Shurgard portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mean what is the outlook for rental rates in Europe?
componenttext: You mean what is the outlook for rental rates in Europe?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, i see. The -- in Europe, we've gotten really aggressive on pricing to drive occupancy, and we've been able to do that. I think we're up 500, 600 basis points year-over-year in occupancy. But the net effect of both of those is that we've still been ab
componenttext: Yes, i see. The -- in Europe, we've gotten really aggressive on pricing to drive occupancy, and we've been able to do that. I think we're up 500, 600 basis points year-over-year in occupancy. But the net effect of both of those is that we've still been able to deliver positive revenue per available foot growth. So while the rates have gone down, the volume has increased greater so revenue growth is positive. I would expect that to continue in 2015 because our average for the year 2014 was about 86%. And Mark and the team over there are targeting to get their portfolio up to 90%, 91%. So I think you'll see probably continued in-place rent movement down, offset by higher volume. And I think we'll see some pretty good top line revenue growth, net-net, out of Shurgard in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about Europe being more active seemingly in the acquisition side. Looking at the press release, you talked about a new EUR 40 million credit facility. Was that meant to be a one-off facility for the acquisitions or is that something that can be
componenttext: You talked about Europe being more active seemingly in the acquisition side. Looking at the press release, you talked about a new EUR 40 million credit facility. Was that meant to be a one-off facility for the acquisitions or is that something that can be expanded and fund anything that's on your plate going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: The EUR 40 million is a revolver, Mike, so it'll -- it has a term of about 3.5 years. So yes, they're putting it in place to help fund the acquisition. But to the extent they do pay it down between now and when the facility expires, they can't redraw on t
