headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Clem Teng, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Clem Teng, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, su
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. 
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, May 1, 2015, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter. We continued to execute on all fronts. In the U.S. and Europe, revenue growth continues to accelerate. Our development pipeline continues to expand and industry fundamentals are good. With that, operator, l
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter. We continued to execute on all fronts. In the U.S. and Europe, revenue growth continues to accelerate. Our development pipeline continues to expand and industry fundamentals are good. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Europe's obviously pretty small at this point relative to everything overall. But can you give us an update on pricing, occupancy, the NOI trends there?
componenttext: Europe's obviously pretty small at this point relative to everything overall. But can you give us an update on pricing, occupancy, the NOI trends there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Occupancy for the quarter was -- for all of Europe was 87.9% versus 82.1% last year, so up 7.1%. Rates were backwards 3% so REVPAF was up close to 4%, 3.8% for the quarter. So we're feeling good about Europe. All markets but one was up in NOI.
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Occupancy for the quarter was -- for all of Europe was 87.9% versus 82.1% last year, so up 7.1%. Rates were backwards 3% so REVPAF was up close to 4%, 3.8% for the quarter. So we're feeling good about Europe. All markets but one was up in NOI. In Holland, our most challenging market, occupancy was 81.4% versus 70.7% last year, so a big 15% increase in occupancy year-over-year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Is there a follow-up or just one question?
componenttext: Great. Is there a follow-up or just one question?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: You can follow up.
componenttext: You can follow up.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: There you go. Can you talk a little bit about the G&A increase relative to prior quarters? And what's a good run rate to expect for the balance of 2015?
componenttext: There you go. Can you talk a little bit about the G&A increase relative to prior quarters? And what's a good run rate to expect for the balance of 2015?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is John. So our G&A for the quarter was about $24 million, and that compared to last year at around $19 million. And the major swing items, the increases were basically in 3 categories. One was share-based compensation expense, which was up abo
componenttext: Mike, this is John. So our G&A for the quarter was about $24 million, and that compared to last year at around $19 million. And the major swing items, the increases were basically in 3 categories. One was share-based compensation expense, which was up about $1 million. The second item was our development overhead that's been expensed. That was up about $0.5 million. And then legal cost, which is up about $4 million for the quarter. So on a run rate basis going forward, I would expect that our G&A, although it's running about $24 million for the quarter, don't think they'll run $24 million for each of the next 3 quarters. But it will continue to run higher than last year, primarily due to, we expect, additional increased legal costs as well as share-based compensation and development overhead cost being expensed, so expect higher G&A going forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. What's the legal cost tied to?
componenttext: Got it. What's the legal cost tied to?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Various litigation matters on various -- I mean, various parts of the company.
componenttext: Various litigation matters on various -- I mean, various parts of the company.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about the traction you're making on rate growth. You obviously saw some good acceleration in 1Q. It appears to be at some of the highest levels in quite a long time. And just how much of an impact lower
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about the traction you're making on rate growth. You obviously saw some good acceleration in 1Q. It appears to be at some of the highest levels in quite a long time. And just how much of an impact lower discount, lower discount is having realized rents move-ins relative to move-outs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, this is John again. For the quarter, our move-in -- our street rates were up about 6% roughly, and our move-in rates were up about a little over 5%. Our volume of move-ins were up about 1.3%. So I'm pretty happy that we're able to move street
componenttext: Yes, Jeremy, this is John again. For the quarter, our move-in -- our street rates were up about 6% roughly, and our move-in rates were up about a little over 5%. Our volume of move-ins were up about 1.3%. So I'm pretty happy that we're able to move street rates and people are accepting these higher rates. We're seeing competition also [indiscernible] street rates, which we really haven't seen a whole lot over the past couple of years. So I got to believe everybody's fairly full and people are getting more aggressive on rates. On the discounting side, at least for the quarter, our discount -- the number of move-ins receiving discounts, the percentage was about the same as the first quarter of last year so roughly about 80% of our move-ins were getting a discount. I expect that as we move forward, given our occupancies, we'll start toning that back. We're starting to do that in the month of April. Street rates continued to move higher in April. They're now somewhere in the neighborhood of about 7% higher, and move-in rates are also moving higher at [indiscernible] so pretty happy about that right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one for Ron if I can. Just a little bit bigger picture on the development front more broadly. Obviously, your guys pipeline grew a little bit this quarter but anecdotally we're hearing about a pick-up from all the new money some just
componenttext: Great. And then just one for Ron if I can. Just a little bit bigger picture on the development front more broadly. Obviously, your guys pipeline grew a little bit this quarter but anecdotally we're hearing about a pick-up from all the new money some just looking for different ways beyond acquisitions and they're looking at more deals. Just kind of given your footprint, where you're seeing sort of nationally the development side.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, we started our development program a couple of years ago in part because acquisition pricing was gaining -- starting to trend above replacement cost. And I'd say, in many cases, well above that, and so we're really happy we got a good develop
componenttext: Yes, Jeremy, we started our development program a couple of years ago in part because acquisition pricing was gaining -- starting to trend above replacement cost. And I'd say, in many cases, well above that, and so we're really happy we got a good development program going. Despite some meaningful deliveries this quarter, we still expanded the pipeline, so we're up to 31 projects, about 3.6 million square feet. We're seeing increased development across the U.S. Is it something to worry about today? No, not really. It's kind of natural, given the comments John just said in terms of rates moving up. It's natural then that developers will look at those rates by us and others and say, "Okay, at those rates, I can develop and make a decent return on capital." I've got Dave Doll here so I'll let him at any color you can on development.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now I think we're pretty happy with the things that we're opening. In fact, we'll open one next Tuesday here in Glendale and continue to see other new development in major markets like Miami, Houston, Dallas but not so much in Southern California, norther
componenttext: Now I think we're pretty happy with the things that we're opening. In fact, we'll open one next Tuesday here in Glendale and continue to see other new development in major markets like Miami, Houston, Dallas but not so much in Southern California, northern California or some of our other key markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the acquisition environment, are you seeing any difference in the composition of potential buyers out there? And also any difference from motivation from sellers if anyone's feeling more of a rush to get deals done now?
componenttext: In terms of the acquisition environment, are you seeing any difference in the composition of potential buyers out there? And also any difference from motivation from sellers if anyone's feeling more of a rush to get deals done now?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not in terms of [indiscernible] Dave Doll again. Not in terms of new equity players. There has been a constant flow of folks trying to come into the marketplace. I don't think that's changed any perception or any -- over the last several quarters. But in
componenttext: Not in terms of [indiscernible] Dave Doll again. Not in terms of new equity players. There has been a constant flow of folks trying to come into the marketplace. I don't think that's changed any perception or any -- over the last several quarters. But in terms of quality of data coming to the marketplace, we don't see high-quality products available today, and hence, it's one of the reasons why we're so happy with our development program. It gives us an opportunity to bring better product to the market they -- to our customers.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of development, you guys are seeing outside of the projects you guys are doing, stuff that's scheduled to come online in your markets. Generally, who are the developers or the operators of these facilities?
componenttext: And then in terms of development, you guys are seeing outside of the projects you guys are doing, stuff that's scheduled to come online in your markets. Generally, who are the developers or the operators of these facilities?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Many of the local regional players that have continued to hold their portfolios have active development programs started. There are a number of developers that had sold out in the prior 2006, '07, '08 time frames. They're back in business again trying to
componenttext: Many of the local regional players that have continued to hold their portfolios have active development programs started. There are a number of developers that had sold out in the prior 2006, '07, '08 time frames. They're back in business again trying to start up development programs. So it's generally people that have had some track record in the business over the years.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind, remember the industry right's got 50,000 facilities. The top 5 operators have less than 10% market share, so the industry's highly fragmented. And that you can extrapolate that into the development programs as well. It's highly fragmented. A
componenttext: Keep in mind, remember the industry right's got 50,000 facilities. The top 5 operators have less than 10% market share, so the industry's highly fragmented. And that you can extrapolate that into the development programs as well. It's highly fragmented. A lot of small 1, 2, 3 property operators doing development programs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was curious, where do you think the portfolio can get from an occupancy standpoint? Is 96% possible in late July? And along those lines, are you seeing any changes in move-out activity related to existing customer rent increases? Any changes in behavior
componenttext: I was curious, where do you think the portfolio can get from an occupancy standpoint? Is 96% possible in late July? And along those lines, are you seeing any changes in move-out activity related to existing customer rent increases? Any changes in behavior around that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start off Ron can jump in. In terms of changes in customer behavior, what rate increases, no, we haven't seen any changes. So they're still very sticky, for the most part, tenants have been with this longer than 1 year, an annual increase, and we're
componenttext: I'll start off Ron can jump in. In terms of changes in customer behavior, what rate increases, no, we haven't seen any changes. So they're still very sticky, for the most part, tenants have been with this longer than 1 year, an annual increase, and we're not seeing any change in that. In fact, we're seeing that our aging of our tenant base is actually -- continues to improve. I think we're at about 56.5%, 57% of our tenants have been here longer than 1 year. So that continues to improve. How high can occupancies get? I don't know I've made an attempt to think 2 years ago saying that get higher than 94% and we're higher than 94%. So can I get to 96%? We have properties that are at 96%. Progress higher than 96%. So there are certain properties and maybe even markets that can get to those levels, but I don't think our entire portfolio can get there.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just add that during April, we had 3 markets where the market as a whole was 97% or better occupied during the month of April. So -- but as an -- I would agree with John to get 2,000 properties at 97% is probably not going to happen.
componenttext: I'll just add that during April, we had 3 markets where the market as a whole was 97% or better occupied during the month of April. So -- but as an -- I would agree with John to get 2,000 properties at 97% is probably not going to happen.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you, as you look back on some of the properties that you acquired, are you reaching stabilization maybe faster than you had expected, given how strong fundamentals are in the business? And as you look forward, do you -- have you changed ou
componenttext: I wanted to ask you, as you look back on some of the properties that you acquired, are you reaching stabilization maybe faster than you had expected, given how strong fundamentals are in the business? And as you look forward, do you -- have you changed our expectations around how long it would take to reach stabilization as you lease up new assets?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ron. Generally, what we do on properties that aren't what we consider stabilized 90-plus percent occupancy is will tend to be a little aggressive, actually a lot aggressive on rates to fill them up. And as they fill up and stabilize, then we'll st
componenttext: This is Ron. Generally, what we do on properties that aren't what we consider stabilized 90-plus percent occupancy is will tend to be a little aggressive, actually a lot aggressive on rates to fill them up. And as they fill up and stabilize, then we'll start to push the street rate and the in-place rents on customers. Are we filling up faster than we anticipated? Yes. You take the Gerard property, which opened in May or June of '13, 4,000 units. And it ended April at 93.9%. I think we forecast that property taking 4 years to fill up, and it's basically filled up in less than 2. So much faster than we anticipate. However, it is at -- filled up at lower rates than we anticipated but we think we'll make that up. And so, net-net, we'll be ahead of the game, and we're seeing that in both our developments and acquisitions. The table that is in the press release, if you look at the '13 acquisitions, 2013 acquisitions kind of give you an indication of what we're doing. Last year, they were at 86.3%. They ended Q1 at 92.8% so up 7.5%. And then you see the contract rents moving from $13.25 to $14 or up 5.7%. So you should expect in that portfolio that maybe occupancy comes up a little bit in terms of stabilization, but the rates will continue to move up at the above average levels for probably the next couple of years because we fill them up at below-market rate.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just wanted to ask you, you announced redemption of some preferred in the quarter. Are you still leaning towards issuing debt at some point, as well for your financing needs and as much as have any or your thoughts around that changed at all?

componenttext: No, we're still looking at a potential issuance of debt sometime in 2015.

componenttext: Ki, this is John. We did expand our line of credit so most likely what we will do this will get -- we will get deep into our line of credit before we start thinking about longer tender debt. But we can do anything from 7 [ph] 10 [ph] 12 [ph] 15 [ph] 30 [ph] I think we can look at the whole spectrum and tranche out that the way we see best fit for Public Storage. We haven't gotten to that point. We have to make a decision yet, but I think we have a lot of options open for us.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe just turning to your same-store expenses. You've done a very good job of keeping it very flat. Most of the REIT companies are [indiscernible] expense increases just curious payroll part of it last quarter, but how are you keeping it flat for a
componenttext: Okay. Maybe just turning to your same-store expenses. You've done a very good job of keeping it very flat. Most of the REIT companies are [indiscernible] expense increases just curious payroll part of it last quarter, but how are you keeping it flat for a while? And noticed that your allocated overhead was favorable to the expense number by $1 million or so. If you can talk about that and how long can this be? Or does it eventually have to return to the stationary?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer to the second part of your question will it return to inflationary rate? Yes, we consistently say that. Having said that, asset also consistently said, we're always working on ways to take cost out of our system to get more efficient, mor
componenttext: Well, the answer to the second part of your question will it return to inflationary rate? Yes, we consistently say that. Having said that, asset also consistently said, we're always working on ways to take cost out of our system to get more efficient, more productive in all aspects of our business. If you look at Q1, a big increase item was snow removal. We're up over $1 million over last year. I can't believe we're up $1 million over last year but we were. Utilities are down. Gas prices are down. Oil prices are down. And so I think -- and we've renegotiated some utility contracts, so I think that number could remain flat to slightly down. Advertising is selling when we're 95% occupied. There's not a lot of need for that. I think when we get to Q2, we didn't do advertising in Q2 last year so you won't see advertising this year so that line will probably be flat. And whether we do advertising the balance of this year is yet to be determined. Other direct property costs were up 3 6 [ph] and then allocated overhead was down mainly because we used annual sales in the first quarter, and we moved it into the third and fourth quarters of last year. And so last year was a double-up and this year, we have the expense savings in Q1.

componenttext: It's a function -- it really varies by market. You've got some of the properties down in Texas. And I think we got one other contract in East Palo Alto that probably has a in-place rent of double what is down in Houston. So just depends on which markets for the properties that are in that quarter's acquisitions. We're not sitting here targeting we want to by properties at $13 or $14 of in-place rents. It's really a function of do we want that property, and therefore, the rent make sense, and so we'll buy it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just snuck in under the wire there. Just a bigger picture question on supply for you. There's a lot of concern over this new supply that's emerging. But in light of your strong operating results, the question is how much new supply does the industry need?
componenttext: Just snuck in under the wire there. Just a bigger picture question on supply for you. There's a lot of concern over this new supply that's emerging. But in light of your strong operating results, the question is how much new supply does the industry need? It seems as though the supply is needed. And when you take a step back Ron, and you look at 8 [ph] square feet per capita, does that seem like the right level going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, I think I said that before and you take the U.S. population 7, 8 square feet per capita, normal population growth of 1% a year or you take 50,000 facilities in 1% percent a year, that's 400 to 500 facilities per year. And that kind of keeps everythi
componenttext: Dave, I think I said that before and you take the U.S. population 7, 8 square feet per capita, normal population growth of 1% a year or you take 50,000 facilities in 1% percent a year, that's 400 to 500 facilities per year. And that kind of keeps everything at 7 or 8 feet per capita. I will tell you as you go across the country, markets vary greatly between 2 and 3 square feet per capita and 12 and 15 square feet per capita. And obviously, the ones that have the highest square footage tend to have lower rate growth. If you ask me where development is -- will happen fastest, New York has been working on development programs for a while, so I think we'll see big uptick or a meaningful uptake in supply in the New York area. And then across the country, it'll vary between in-fill markets and then outlying markets where it's easier to get zoning, permitting and land is cheaper. But 400 to 500 properties a year kind of keeps things static, and we haven't had much development since '09. So we're kind of 4, 5 years behind in terms of the curve of new supply relative to organic population growth.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So the industry saw a significant secular shift in terms of growth of square feet per capita of maybe 3 20 years ago to 8 today. It seems like your thought is that we grow in line with -- a growth in line with population, growth would make sense th
componenttext: Right. So the industry saw a significant secular shift in terms of growth of square feet per capita of maybe 3 20 years ago to 8 today. It seems like your thought is that we grow in line with -- a growth in line with population, growth would make sense that not these results, the demand that we're seeing don't necessarily indicate that we need 9 or 10 square feet per capita.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I guess my point in mentioning the 9 or 10 or like I know Austin's got over 11 feet per -- square feet per capita and Austin is a pretty good market for us. So is the max 7? I don't think so. It varies by market. And could the country -- in the
componenttext: Yes. Well, I guess my point in mentioning the 9 or 10 or like I know Austin's got over 11 feet per -- square feet per capita and Austin is a pretty good market for us. So is the max 7? I don't think so. It varies by market. And could the country -- in the U.S., could we go to a 10 or 11 square foot per capita? I don't think that's unreasonable, given the trend to movement into apartments, smaller homes, especially in markets like Manhattan and San Francisco and even parts of L.A. It's not impossible to get to a 10 or 11 per square foot. Is that going to happen? I can't say.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, su
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, May 1, 2015, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
A reconciliation to GAAP and the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter. We continued to execute on all fronts. In the U.S. and Europe, revenue growth continues to accelerate. Our development pipeline continues to expand, and industry fundamentals are good. With that, operator,
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter. We continued to execute on all fronts. In the U.S. and Europe, revenue growth continues to accelerate. Our development pipeline continues to expand, and industry fundamentals are good. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Europe's obviously pretty small at this point relative to everything overall. But could you give us an update on pricing, occupancy, the NOI trends there?
componenttext: Europe's obviously pretty small at this point relative to everything overall. But could you give us an update on pricing, occupancy, the NOI trends there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Occupancy for the quarter was -- for all of Europe was 87.9% versus 82.1% last year, so up 7.1%. Rates were backwards 3%, so REVPAF was up close to 4%, 3.8% for the quarter. So we're feeling good about Europe. All markets but one was up in NOI
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Occupancy for the quarter was -- for all of Europe was 87.9% versus 82.1% last year, so up 7.1%. Rates were backwards 3%, so REVPAF was up close to 4%, 3.8% for the quarter. So we're feeling good about Europe. All markets but one was up in NOI. And Holland, our most challenging market, occupancy was 81.4% versus 70.7% last year, so big 15% increase in occupancy year-over-year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I forget, is there a follow-up? Or is it just one question?
componenttext: Great. I forget, is there a follow-up? Or is it just one question?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: You can follow up.
componenttext: You can follow up.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: There you go. Could you talk a little bit about the G&A increase relative to prior quarters? And what's a good run rate to expect for the balance of 2015?
componenttext: There you go. Could you talk a little bit about the G&A increase relative to prior quarters? And what's a good run rate to expect for the balance of 2015?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is John. So our G&A for the quarter was about $24 million, and that compared to last year at around $19 million. And the major swing items, the increases, were basically in 3 categories: one was share-based compensation expense, which was up ab
componenttext: Mike, this is John. So our G&A for the quarter was about $24 million, and that compared to last year at around $19 million. And the major swing items, the increases, were basically in 3 categories: one was share-based compensation expense, which was up about $1 million; the second item was our development overhead that's been expensed. That was up about $0.5 million; and then legal costs, which is up about $4 million for the quarter. So on a run rate basis going forward, I would expect that our G&A, although it's running about $24 million for the quarter, don't think they'll run $24 million for each of the next 3 quarters. But it will continue to run higher than last year, primarily due to -- we expect additional increased legal costs as well as share-based compensation and development overhead cost being expensed, so expect higher G&A going forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. What's the legal cost tied to?
componenttext: Got it. What's the legal cost tied to?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Various litigation matters on various -- I mean, various parts of the company.
componenttext: Various litigation matters on various -- I mean, various parts of the company.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the traction you're making on rate growth. You obviously saw some good acceleration in 1Q. It appears to be at some of the highest levels in quite a long time. And ju
componenttext: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the traction you're making on rate growth. You obviously saw some good acceleration in 1Q. It appears to be at some of the highest levels in quite a long time. And just how much of an impact lower discount is having realized and where realized rents for move-ins where -- relative to move-outs?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, this is John again. For the quarter, our move-in -- our street rates are up about 6%, roughly, and our move-in rates were up about a little over 5%. Our volume of move-ins were up about 1.3%. So I'm pretty happy that we're able to move street
componenttext: Yes, Jeremy, this is John again. For the quarter, our move-in -- our street rates are up about 6%, roughly, and our move-in rates were up about a little over 5%. Our volume of move-ins were up about 1.3%. So I'm pretty happy that we're able to move street rates and people are accepting these higher rates. We're seeing competition also raise their street rates, which we really haven't seen a whole lot over the past couple of years. So I got to believe everybody is fairly full and people are getting more aggressive on rates. On the discounting side, at least for the quarter, our discount -- the number of move-ins receiving discounts was -- the percentage was about the same as it has the first quarter of last year, so roughly about 80% of our move-ins were getting a discount. I expect that as we move forward, given our occupancies, we'll start toning that back, and we're starting to do that in the month of April. Street rates continue to move higher in April. They're now somewhere in the neighborhood of about 7% higher, and move-in rates are also moving higher at [indiscernible], so pretty happy about that right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one for Ron, if I can. Just a little bit bigger picture on the development front more broadly. Obviously, you guys pipeline grew a little bit this quarter, but anecdotally, we're hearing about a pickup from all the new money trying to
componenttext: Great. And then just one for Ron, if I can. Just a little bit bigger picture on the development front more broadly. Obviously, you guys pipeline grew a little bit this quarter, but anecdotally, we're hearing about a pickup from all the new money trying to enter storage, just looking for different ways beyond acquisitions and they're looking at more CO deals. Just kind of given your footprint, what you're seeing sort of nationally on the development side?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, we started our development program a couple of years ago, in part because acquisition pricing was getting -- starting to trend above replacement cost. And I'd say it's, in many cases, well above that. And so we're really happy we've got a goo
componenttext: Yes, Jeremy, we started our development program a couple of years ago, in part because acquisition pricing was getting -- starting to trend above replacement cost. And I'd say it's, in many cases, well above that. And so we're really happy we've got a good development program going. Despite some meaningful deliveries this quarter, we still expanded the pipeline. So we're up to 31 projects, about 3.6 million square feet. We're seeing increased development across the U.S. Is it something to worry about today? No, not really. It's kind of natural, given the comments John just said in terms of rates moving up. It's natural then that developers will look at those rates by us and others and say, "Okay, at those rates, I can develop and make a decent return on capital." I've got Dave Doll here so I'll let him at it. Any color you've got on developments?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: No I think we're pretty happy with the things that we're opening. In fact, we'll open one next Tuesday here in Glendale and continue to see other new development in major markets like Miami, Houston, Dallas, but not so much in Southern California, Norther
componenttext: No I think we're pretty happy with the things that we're opening. In fact, we'll open one next Tuesday here in Glendale and continue to see other new development in major markets like Miami, Houston, Dallas, but not so much in Southern California, Northern California or some of our other key markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In term of the acquisition environment, are you seeing any difference in the composition of potential buyers out there? And also any difference from the motivation from sellers, if anyone's feeling more of a rush to get deals done now?
componenttext: Yes. In term of the acquisition environment, are you seeing any difference in the composition of potential buyers out there? And also any difference from the motivation from sellers, if anyone's feeling more of a rush to get deals done now?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not in terms of -- Dave Doll again. Not in terms of new equity players. There has been a constant inflow of folks trying to come into the marketplace. I don't think that's changed any perception or any -- over the last several quarters. But in terms of qu
componenttext: Not in terms of -- Dave Doll again. Not in terms of new equity players. There has been a constant inflow of folks trying to come into the marketplace. I don't think that's changed any perception or any -- over the last several quarters. But in terms of quality of product coming to the marketplace, we don't see high-quality products available today, and hence, it's one of the reasons why we're so happy with our development program. It gives us an opportunity to bring better product to the market player or to our customers.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of development you guys are seeing outside of the projects you guys are doing, stuff that's scheduled to come online in your markets, generally, who are the developers or the operators of these facilities?
componenttext: And then in terms of development you guys are seeing outside of the projects you guys are doing, stuff that's scheduled to come online in your markets, generally, who are the developers or the operators of these facilities?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Many of the local regional players that have continued to hold their portfolios have active development programs started. There are a number of developers that had sold out in the prior 2006, '07, '08 time frames. They're back in business again trying to
componenttext: Many of the local regional players that have continued to hold their portfolios have active development programs started. There are a number of developers that had sold out in the prior 2006, '07, '08 time frames. They're back in business again trying to start up development programs. So it's generally people that have had some track record in the business over the years.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind, remember the industry, right, has got 50,000 facilities. The top 5 operators have less than 10% market share. So the industry is highly fragmented. So -- and that's -- you can extrapolate that into the development programs as well. It's high
componenttext: Keep in mind, remember the industry, right, has got 50,000 facilities. The top 5 operators have less than 10% market share. So the industry is highly fragmented. So -- and that's -- you can extrapolate that into the development programs as well. It's highly fragmented, a lot of small 1, 2, 3 property operators doing development programs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was curious, where do you think the portfolio can get from an occupancy standpoint? Is 96% possible in late July? And along those lines, are you seeing any changes in move-out activity related to existing customer rent increases? Any changes in behavior
componenttext: I was curious, where do you think the portfolio can get from an occupancy standpoint? Is 96% possible in late July? And along those lines, are you seeing any changes in move-out activity related to existing customer rent increases? Any changes in behavior around that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Todd, I'll start off and Ron can jump in. In terms of changes in customer behavior with rate increases, no, we haven't seen any changes. So they're still very sticky. For the most part, we're sending tenants who have been with us longer than a year an ann
componenttext: Todd, I'll start off and Ron can jump in. In terms of changes in customer behavior with rate increases, no, we haven't seen any changes. So they're still very sticky. For the most part, we're sending tenants who have been with us longer than a year an annual increase, and we're not seeing any change in that. In fact, we're seeing that our aging of our tenant base is actually -- continues to improve. I think we're at about 56.5%. 57% of our tenants have been here longer than a year. So that continues to improve. How high can occupancies get? I don't know I've made an attempt to think 2 years ago saying that I don't think they get higher than 94% and we're higher than 94%. So can I get to 96%? We have properties that are at 96%. We have properties that are probably higher than 96%. So there are certain properties and maybe even markets that can get to those levels, but I don't think our entire portfolio can get there.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just add. During April, we had 3 markets where the market as a whole was 97% or better occupied during the month of April. So -- but as John -- so I would agree with John, to get 2,000 properties at 97% is probably not going to happen.
componenttext: Yes, I'll just add. During April, we had 3 markets where the market as a whole was 97% or better occupied during the month of April. So -- but as John -- so I would agree with John, to get 2,000 properties at 97% is probably not going to happen.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then if I can just follow-up. With regard to the litigation matters, I mean, can you just shed some light on what that pertains to? It seems like sort of a big number. And is that something that you foresee continuing throughout
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then if I can just follow-up. With regard to the litigation matters, I mean, can you just shed some light on what that pertains to? It seems like sort of a big number. And is that something that you foresee continuing throughout the balance of the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Whatever we could talk about will be in the 10-Q, so that's what you should read to get kind of clarity on the litigation.
componenttext: Whatever we could talk about will be in the 10-Q, so that's what you should read to get kind of clarity on the litigation.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you, as you look back on some of the properties that you'd acquired that -- are you reaching stabilization maybe faster than you had expected, given how strong fundamentals are in the business? And as you look forward, do you -- have you c
componenttext: I wanted to ask you, as you look back on some of the properties that you'd acquired that -- are you reaching stabilization maybe faster than you had expected, given how strong fundamentals are in the business? And as you look forward, do you -- have you changed your expectations around how long it would take to reach stabilization as you lease up new assets?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Smedes, this is Ron. Generally, what we do on properties that aren't what we'd consider stabilized, 90-plus percent occupancy, is we'll be -- tend to be a little aggressive, actually, a lot aggressive on rate to fill them up. And as they fill up and stabi
componenttext: Smedes, this is Ron. Generally, what we do on properties that aren't what we'd consider stabilized, 90-plus percent occupancy, is we'll be -- tend to be a little aggressive, actually, a lot aggressive on rate to fill them up. And as they fill up and stabilize, then we'll start to push the street rate and the in-place rents on customers. Are we filling up faster than we anticipated? Yes. You take the Gerard property, which opened in May or June of '13, 4,000 units, and it ended April at 93.9%. I think we forecast that property taking 4 years to fill up, and it's basically filled up in less than 2. So much faster than we anticipate. However, it is at -- filled up at lower rates than we anticipated, but we think we'll make that up. And so net-net, we'll be ahead of the game, and we're seeing that in both our developments and acquisitions. The table that is in the press release, if you look at the '13 acquisitions, 2013 acquisitions, they kind of give you an indication of what we're doing. Last year, they were at 86.3%. They ended Q1 at 92.8%, so up 7.5%. And then you see the contract rents moving from $13.25 to $14 or up 5.7%. So you should expect in that portfolio that maybe occupancy comes up a little bit in terms of stabilization, but the rates will continue to move up at above-average levels for probably the next couple of years because we fill them up at below-market rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just wanted to ask you, you announced redemption of some preferred in the quarter. Are you still leaning towards issuing debt at some point as well for your financing needs, in as much as you have any, but -- or has your t
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just wanted to ask you, you announced redemption of some preferred in the quarter. Are you still leaning towards issuing debt at some point as well for your financing needs, in as much as you have any, but -- or has your thoughts around that changed at all?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we're still looking at potential issuance of debt sometime in 2015.
componenttext: No, we're still looking at potential issuance of debt sometime in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just following up on the last question. I -- if you did pursue debt, where's your mindset? Because obviously you extend your line of credit. Is it more shorter-term duration? Or are you looking more at a 30-year type of range?
componenttext: So just following up on the last question. I -- if you did pursue debt, where's your mindset? Because obviously you extend your line of credit. Is it more shorter-term duration? Or are you looking more at a 30-year type of range?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ki Bin, this is John. Well, we did extend our line of credit. So most likely what we'll do this is we'll get in, we get in deep into our line of credit before we start thinking about longer tenor debt. But we can do anything from 7, 10, 12, 15, 30. I thin
componenttext: Ki Bin, this is John. Well, we did extend our line of credit. So most likely what we'll do this is we'll get in, we get in deep into our line of credit before we start thinking about longer tenor debt. But we can do anything from 7, 10, 12, 15, 30. I think we can look at the whole spectrum and tranche out debt the way we see best fit for Public Storage. We haven't gotten to that point to have to make a decision yet, but I think we have a lot of options open for us.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe just turning to your same-store expenses. You've done a very good job of keeping it very flat. Most REIT -- other REIT companies are expecting a lot of expense increases. Just curious, besides the payroll part of it, which stopped [ph] at last
componenttext: Okay. Maybe just turning to your same-store expenses. You've done a very good job of keeping it very flat. Most REIT -- other REIT companies are expecting a lot of expense increases. Just curious, besides the payroll part of it, which stopped [ph] at last quarter, but how are you keeping it flat for a while? And I noticed that your allocated overhead was favorable to the expense number by $1 million or so, if you could talk about that. And how long can this be? Or does it eventually have to return to like an inflationary rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer to the second part of your question, will it return long term to an inflationary rate? Yes, we consistently say that. Having said that -- because we've also consistently said we're always working on ways to take costs out of our system, t
componenttext: Well, the answer to the second part of your question, will it return long term to an inflationary rate? Yes, we consistently say that. Having said that -- because we've also consistently said we're always working on ways to take costs out of our system, to get more efficient, more productive in all aspects of our business. If you look at Q1, a big increase item was snow removal. We're up $1 million over last year. I can't believe we're up $1 million over last year, but we were. Utilities are down. Gas prices are down. Oil prices are down. And so I think -- and we've renegotiated some utility contracts, so I think that number could remain flat to slightly down. Advertising to selling, when we're 95% occupied, there's not a lot of need for that. I think when we get to Q2, we didn't do advertising in Q2 last year, so you won't see advertising this year. So that line will probably be flat. And whether we do advertising, the balance of this year is yet to be determined. Other direct property tax costs were up 3.6% and then allocated overhead was down mainly because we used to have our annual sales conference in the first quarter, and we moved it into the third and fourth quarters of last year. And so last year was a double-up, and this year, we have the expense savings in Q1.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: For the acquisitions already completed this year, the annual contract rent is $1,165 and just lower than some of the previous years. Is there anything we can read into that number? Is there a reflection of markets you're entering or any CO deals included
componenttext: For the acquisitions already completed this year, the annual contract rent is $1,165 and just lower than some of the previous years. Is there anything we can read into that number? Is there a reflection of markets you're entering or any CO deals included in that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a function -- Todd, it really varies by market. You've got some of the properties are down in Texas. And I think we got one under contract in East Palo Alto that probably has a in-place rent of double what is down in Houston. So just depends on which
componenttext: It's a function -- Todd, it really varies by market. You've got some of the properties are down in Texas. And I think we got one under contract in East Palo Alto that probably has a in-place rent of double what is down in Houston. So just depends on which markets for the properties that are in that quarter's acquisitions. We're not sitting here targeting we want to buy properties at $13 or $14 of in-place rents. It's really a function of do we want that property as -- and therefore, the rent make sense, and so we'll buy it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe the sample size is small, and I'm looking at...
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe the sample size is small, and I'm looking at...

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: And then just second, can you provide any color on the land lease buyout that you had in Q1?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, with remnant transaction from the Shurgard merger in '06, and we had an option to acquire the land lease this year. And so with a predetermined formula, and we exercised our option and closed on the transaction. It's a pretty good transaction for us.
componenttext: Yes, with remnant transaction from the Shurgard merger in '06, and we had an option to acquire the land lease this year. And so with a predetermined formula, and we exercised our option and closed on the transaction. It's a pretty good transaction for us. Only $15 million, but it's a pretty good transaction.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: You do have a question from Dave Bragg of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: You do have a question from Dave Bragg of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just snuck in under the wire there. Just a bigger-picture question on supply for you. There's a lot of concern over this new supply that's emerging. But in light of your strong operating results, the question is how much new supply does the industry need?
componenttext: Just snuck in under the wire there. Just a bigger-picture question on supply for you. There's a lot of concern over this new supply that's emerging. But in light of your strong operating results, the question is how much new supply does the industry need? It seems as though the supply is needed. And when you take a step back Ron and you look at 8 square feet per capita, does that seem like the right level going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, I think I've said that before. And you kind of -- you take the U.S. population 7, 8 square feet per capita, normal population growth of 1% a year or you can take 50,000 facilities and 1% percent a year, that's 400 to 500 facilities per year. And tha
componenttext: Dave, I think I've said that before. And you kind of -- you take the U.S. population 7, 8 square feet per capita, normal population growth of 1% a year or you can take 50,000 facilities and 1% percent a year, that's 400 to 500 facilities per year. And that kind of keeps everything at 7 or 8 feet per capita. I will tell you as you go across the country, markets vary greatly between 2 and 3 square feet per capita and 12 and 15 square feet per capita. And obviously, the ones that have the highest square footage tend to have lower rate growth. If you ask me where development is -- will happen fastest, New York has been working on development programs for a while, so I think we'll see big uptick or meaningful uptick in supply in the New York area. And then across the country, it'll vary between in-fill markets and then outlying markets, where it's easier to get zoning, permitting and land is cheaper. But 400 to 500 properties a year kind of keeps things static, and we haven't had much development since '09. So we're kind of 4, 5 years behind in terms of the curve of new supply relative to organic population growth.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So the industry saw a significant secular shift in terms of a growth of square feet per capita of maybe 3 20 years ago to 8 today. It seems like your thought is that we grow in line with -- a growth in line with population. Growth would make sense
componenttext: Right. So the industry saw a significant secular shift in terms of a growth of square feet per capita of maybe 3 20 years ago to 8 today. It seems like your thought is that we grow in line with -- a growth in line with population. Growth would make sense that we're -- not these results. The demand that we're seeing don't necessarily indicate that we need 9 or 10 square feet per capita.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I guess my point in mentioning the 9 or 10 or the -- like I know Austin's got over 11 feet per -- square feet per capita, and Austin's a pretty good market for us. So is the max 7? I don't think so. It varies by market. And could the country --
componenttext: Yes. Well, I guess my point in mentioning the 9 or 10 or the -- like I know Austin's got over 11 feet per -- square feet per capita, and Austin's a pretty good market for us. So is the max 7? I don't think so. It varies by market. And could the country -- in the U.S., could we go to a 10 or 11 square foot per capita? I don't think that's unreasonable, given the trend toward movement to apartments, smaller homes, especially in markets like Manhattan and San Francisco and even parts of L.A. It's not impossible to get to a 10 or 11 per square foot. Is that going to happen? I can't say.

componenttextpreview: By committee?
componenttext: By committee?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: With a team.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, just the -- the 3 report effectively. And I ask it more so because I think the COO role has had some turnover over the last 5 or 6 years. I think Shawn may have been the third in that seat. So I didn't know if there was something structurally that w
componenttext: Well, just the -- the 3 report effectively. And I ask it more so because I think the COO role has had some turnover over the last 5 or 6 years. I think Shawn may have been the third in that seat. So I didn't know if there was something structurally that wasn't working. Just talk about what was -- what has -- and maybe there are just reasons why each of them left, but...

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are different reasons why each of them left, but you can ascribe it to my inability to hire a COO. So I'll just leave it at that. But the guys we have running the operations are longtime Public Storage execs that have grown up here in the operations
componenttext: There are different reasons why each of them left, but you can ascribe it to my inability to hire a COO. So I'll just leave it at that. But the guys we have running the operations are longtime Public Storage execs that have grown up here in the operations. And they just -- well, you could tell by the results, they're doing an exceptional job.
