componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Clem Teng, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, su
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, May 1, 2015, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
A reconciliation to GAAP and the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter. We continued to execute on all fronts. In the U.S. and Europe, revenue growth continues to accelerate. Our development pipeline continues to expand and industry fundamentals are good. With that, operator, l
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter. We continued to execute on all fronts. In the U.S. and Europe, revenue growth continues to accelerate. Our development pipeline continues to expand and industry fundamentals are good. 
With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Europe's obviously pretty small at this point relative to everything overall. But could you give us an update on pricing, occupancy, the NOI trends there?
componenttext: Europe's obviously pretty small at this point relative to everything overall. But could you give us an update on pricing, occupancy, the NOI trends there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Occupancy for the quarter was -- for all of Europe was 87.9% versus 82.1% last year, so up 7.1%. Rates were backwards 3%, so REVPAF was up close to 4%, 3.8% for the quarter. So we're feeling good about Europe. All markets but one was up in NOI
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Occupancy for the quarter was -- for all of Europe was 87.9% versus 82.1% last year, so up 7.1%. Rates were backwards 3%, so REVPAF was up close to 4%, 3.8% for the quarter. So we're feeling good about Europe. All markets but one was up in NOI. And Holland, our most challenging market, occupancy was 81.4% versus 70.7% last year, so big 15% increase in occupancy year-over-year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I forget, is there a follow-up? Or is it just one question?
componenttext: Great. I forget, is there a follow-up? Or is it just one question?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: You can follow up.
componenttext: You can follow up.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: There you go. Could you talk a little bit about the G&A increase relative to prior quarters? And what's a good run rate to expect for the balance of 2015?
componenttext: There you go. Could you talk a little bit about the G&A increase relative to prior quarters? And what's a good run rate to expect for the balance of 2015?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is John. So our G&A for the quarter was about $24 million, and that compared to last year at around $19 million. And the major swing items, the increases, were basically in 3 categories: one was share-based compensation expense, which was up ab
componenttext: Mike, this is John. So our G&A for the quarter was about $24 million, and that compared to last year at around $19 million. And the major swing items, the increases, were basically in 3 categories: one was share-based compensation expense, which was up about $1 million; the second item was our development overhead that's being expensed. That was up about $0.5 million; and then legal costs, which is up about $4 million for the quarter. So on a run rate basis going forward, I would expect that our G&A, although it's running about $24 million for the quarter, don't think it'll run $24 million for each of the next 3 quarters. But it will continue to run higher than last year, primarily due to, we expect additional increased legal costs, as well as share-based compensation and development overhead cost being expensed, so expect higher G&A going forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. What's the legal cost tied to?
componenttext: Got it. What's the legal cost tied to?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Various litigation matters on various -- I mean, various parts of the company.
componenttext: Various litigation matters on various -- I mean, various parts of the company.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the traction you're making on rate growth. You obviously saw some good acceleration in 1Q. It appears to be at some of the highest levels in quite a long time. And ju
componenttext: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the traction you're making on rate growth. You obviously saw some good acceleration in 1Q. It appears to be at some of the highest levels in quite a long time. And just how much of an impact lower discounting is having, and where realized rents for move-ins were relative to move-outs?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, this is John again. For the quarter, our move-in -- our street rates were up about 6%, roughly, and our move-in rates were up about a little over 5%. Our volume of move-ins were up about 1.3%. So I'm pretty happy that we're able to move stree
componenttext: Yes, Jeremy, this is John again. For the quarter, our move-in -- our street rates were up about 6%, roughly, and our move-in rates were up about a little over 5%. Our volume of move-ins were up about 1.3%. So I'm pretty happy that we're able to move street rates and people are accepting those higher rates. We're seeing competition also raise their street rates, which we really hadn't seen a whole lot over the past couple of years. So I got to believe everybody is fairly full and people are getting more aggressive on rates. On the discounting side, at least for the quarter, our discount -- the number of move-ins receiving discounts was -- the percentage was about the same as it has the first quarter of last year, so roughly about 80% of our move-ins were getting a discount. I expect that as we move forward, given our occupancies, we'll start toning that back, and we're starting to do that in the month of April. Street rates continue to move higher in April. They're now somewhere in the neighborhood of about 7% higher, and move-in rates are also moving higher at this point in time, so pretty happy about that right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one for Ron, if I can. Just a little bit bigger picture on the development front more broadly. Obviously, your guys' pipeline grew a little bit this quarter, but anecdotally, we're hearing about a pickup from all the new money trying
componenttext: Great. And then just one for Ron, if I can. Just a little bit bigger picture on the development front more broadly. Obviously, your guys' pipeline grew a little bit this quarter, but anecdotally, we're hearing about a pickup from all the new money trying to enter storage, it's looking for different ways beyond acquisitions and they're looking at more C/O deals. Just kind of given your footprint, what you're seeing sort of nationally on the development side?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, we started our development program a couple of years ago, in part because acquisition pricing was getting -- starting to trend above replacement cost. And I'd say it's, in many cases, well above that. And so we're really happy we've got a goo
componenttext: Yes, Jeremy, we started our development program a couple of years ago, in part because acquisition pricing was getting -- starting to trend above replacement cost. And I'd say it's, in many cases, well above that. And so we're really happy we've got a good development program going. Despite some meaningful deliveries this quarter, we still expanded the pipeline. So we're up to 31 projects, about 3.6 million square feet. We're seeing increased development across the U.S. Is it something to worry about today? No, not really. It's kind of natural, given the comments John just said in terms of rates moving up. It's natural then that developers will look at those rates by us and others and say, "Okay, at those rates, I can develop and make a decent return on capital." I've got Dave Doll here so I'll let him add. Any color you've got on developments?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think we're pretty happy with the things that we're opening. In fact, we'll open one next Tuesday here in Glendale and continue to see other new development in major markets like Miami, Houston, Dallas, but not so much in Southern California, Northe
componenttext: No, I think we're pretty happy with the things that we're opening. In fact, we'll open one next Tuesday here in Glendale and continue to see other new development in major markets like Miami, Houston, Dallas, but not so much in Southern California, Northern California or some of our other key markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the acquisition environment, are you seeing any difference in the composition of potential buyers out there? And also, any difference from the motivation from sellers, if anyone's feeling more of a rush to get deals done nowadays?
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the acquisition environment, are you seeing any difference in the composition of potential buyers out there? And also, any difference from the motivation from sellers, if anyone's feeling more of a rush to get deals done nowadays?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not in terms of -- Dave Doll again. Not in terms of new equity players. There has been a constant inflow of folks trying to come into the marketplace. I don't think that's changed any perception or any -- over the last several quarters. But in terms of qu
componenttext: Not in terms of -- Dave Doll again. Not in terms of new equity players. There has been a constant inflow of folks trying to come into the marketplace. I don't think that's changed any perception or any -- over the last several quarters. But in terms of quality of product coming to the marketplace, we don't see high-quality product available today, and hence, it's one of the reasons why we're so happy with our development program. It gives us an opportunity to bring better product to the marketplace -- or to our customers.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of development you guys are seeing outside of the projects you guys are doing, stuff that's scheduled to come online in your markets, generally, who are the developers or the operators of these facilities?
componenttext: And then in terms of development you guys are seeing outside of the projects you guys are doing, stuff that's scheduled to come online in your markets, generally, who are the developers or the operators of these facilities?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Many of the local regional players that have continued to hold their portfolios have active development programs started. There are a number of developers that had sold out in the prior 2006, '07, '08 timeframes. They're back in business again trying to s
componenttext: Many of the local regional players that have continued to hold their portfolios have active development programs started. There are a number of developers that had sold out in the prior 2006, '07, '08 timeframes. They're back in business again trying to start up development programs. So it's generally people that have had some track record in the business over the years.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind, remember the industry, right, has got 50,000 facilities. The top 5 operators have less than 10% market share. So the industry is highly fragmented. So -- and that's -- you can extrapolate that into the development programs as well. It's high
componenttext: Keep in mind, remember the industry, right, has got 50,000 facilities. The top 5 operators have less than 10% market share. So the industry is highly fragmented. So -- and that's -- you can extrapolate that into the development programs as well. It's highly fragmented, a lot of small 1, 2, 3 property operators doing development programs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was curious, where do you think the portfolio can get from an occupancy standpoint? Is 96% possible in late July? And along those lines, are you seeing any changes in move-out activity related to existing customer rent increases? Any changes in behavior
componenttext: I was curious, where do you think the portfolio can get from an occupancy standpoint? Is 96% possible in late July? And along those lines, are you seeing any changes in move-out activity related to existing customer rent increases? Any changes in behavior around that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Todd, I'll start and Ron can jump in. In terms of changes in customer behavior with rate increases, no, we haven't seen any changes. So they're still very sticky. For the most part, we're sending tenants who have been with us longer than a year an annual
componenttext: Todd, I'll start and Ron can jump in. In terms of changes in customer behavior with rate increases, no, we haven't seen any changes. So they're still very sticky. For the most part, we're sending tenants who have been with us longer than a year an annual increase, and we're not seeing any change in that. In fact, we're seeing that our aging of our tenant base is actually -- continues to improve. I think we're at about 56.5%, 57% of our tenants have been here longer than a year. So that continues to improve. How high can occupancies get? I don't know, I've made an attempt to, I think 2 years ago, saying that I don't think they can get higher than 94% and we're higher than 94%. So can I get to 96%? We have properties that are at 96%. We have properties that are probably higher than 96%. So there are certain properties and maybe even markets that can get to those levels, but I don't think our entire portfolio can get there.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just add, during April, we had 3 markets where the market as a whole was 97% or better occupied during the month of April. So -- but as John said, I would agree with John, to get 2,000 properties at 97% is probably not going to happen.
componenttext: Yes, I'll just add, during April, we had 3 markets where the market as a whole was 97% or better occupied during the month of April. So -- but as John said, I would agree with John, to get 2,000 properties at 97% is probably not going to happen.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then if I can just follow up. With regard to the litigation matters, I mean, can you just shed some light on what that pertains to? It seems like sort of a big number. And is that something that you foresee continuing throughout
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then if I can just follow up. With regard to the litigation matters, I mean, can you just shed some light on what that pertains to? It seems like sort of a big number. And is that something that you foresee continuing throughout the balance of the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Whatever we could talk about will be in the 10-Q, so that's what you should read to get kind of clarity on the litigation.
componenttext: Whatever we could talk about will be in the 10-Q, so that's what you should read to get kind of clarity on the litigation.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you, as you look back on some of the properties that you'd acquired that -- are you reaching stabilization maybe faster than you had expected, given how strong fundamentals are in the business? And as you look forward, do you -- have you c
componenttext: I wanted to ask you, as you look back on some of the properties that you'd acquired that -- are you reaching stabilization maybe faster than you had expected, given how strong fundamentals are in the business? And as you look forward, do you -- have you changed your expectations around how long it would take to reach stabilization as you lease up new assets?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Smedes, this is Ron. Generally, what we do on properties that aren't what we'd consider stabilized, 90-plus percent occupancy, is we'll be -- tend to be a little aggressive, actually, a lot aggressive, on rate to fill them up. And as they fill up and stab
componenttext: Smedes, this is Ron. Generally, what we do on properties that aren't what we'd consider stabilized, 90-plus percent occupancy, is we'll be -- tend to be a little aggressive, actually, a lot aggressive, on rate to fill them up. And as they fill up and stabilize, then we'll start to push the street rate and the in-place rents on customers. Are we filling up faster than we anticipated? Yes. You take the Gerard property, which opened in May or June of '13, 4,000 units, and it ended April at 93.9%. I think we forecast that property taking 4 years to fill up, and it's basically filled up in less than 2. So much faster than we anticipated. However, it is at -- filled up at lower rates than we anticipated, but we think we'll make that up. And so net-net, we'll be ahead of the game, and we're seeing that in both our developments and acquisitions. The table that is in the press release, if you look at the '13 acquisitions, 2013 acquisitions, they kind of give you an indication of what we're doing. Last year, they were at 86.3%. They ended Q1 at 92.8%, so up 7.5%. And then you see the contract rents moving from $13.25 to $14 or up 5.7%. So you should expect in that portfolio that maybe occupancy comes up a little bit in terms of stabilization, but that the rates will continue to move up at above-average levels for probably the next couple of years, because we fill them up at below-market rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just wanted to ask you, you announced redemption of some preferred in the quarter. Are you still leaning towards issuing debt at some point as well for your financing needs, inasmuch as you have any, but -- or has your tho
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I just wanted to ask you, you announced redemption of some preferred in the quarter. Are you still leaning towards issuing debt at some point as well for your financing needs, inasmuch as you have any, but -- or has your thoughts around that changed at all?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we're still looking at potential issuance of debt sometime in 2015.
componenttext: No, we're still looking at potential issuance of debt sometime in 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just following up on that last question. I -- if you did pursue debt, where's your mindset? Because obviously, you extend your line of credit. Is it more shorter-term duration? Or are you looking more at a 30-year type of range?
componenttext: So just following up on that last question. I -- if you did pursue debt, where's your mindset? Because obviously, you extend your line of credit. Is it more shorter-term duration? Or are you looking more at a 30-year type of range?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ki Bin, this is John. Well, we did expand our line of credit. So most likely what we'll do is we'll get in, we'll get in deep into our line of credit before we start thinking about longer tenor debt. But we can do anything from 7, 10, 12, 15, 30. I think
componenttext: Ki Bin, this is John. Well, we did expand our line of credit. So most likely what we'll do is we'll get in, we'll get in deep into our line of credit before we start thinking about longer tenor debt. But we can do anything from 7, 10, 12, 15, 30. I think we can look at the whole spectrum and tranche out debt the way we see best fit for Public Storage. We haven't gotten to that point to have to make a decision yet, but I think we have a lot of options open for us.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe just turning to your same-store expenses. You've done a very good job of keeping it very flat. And other -- most REIT, other REIT companies, are experiencing a lot of expense increases. Just curious, besides the payroll part of it, which you t
componenttext: Okay. Maybe just turning to your same-store expenses. You've done a very good job of keeping it very flat. And other -- most REIT, other REIT companies, are experiencing a lot of expense increases. Just curious, besides the payroll part of it, which you talked at last quarter, but how are you keeping it flat so well? And I noticed that your allocated overhead was favorable to the expense number by $1 million or so, if you could talk about that. And how long can this stay? Or does it eventually have to return to like an inflationary rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer to the second part of your question, will it return long term to an inflationary rate? Yes, we consistently say that. Having said that, as we've also consistently said, we're always working on ways to take costs out of our system, to get
componenttext: Well, the answer to the second part of your question, will it return long term to an inflationary rate? Yes, we consistently say that. Having said that, as we've also consistently said, we're always working on ways to take costs out of our system, to get more efficient, more productive in all aspects of our business. If you look at Q1, a big increase item was snow removal. We're up $1 million over last year. I can't believe we're up $1 million over last year, but we were. Utilities are down. Gas prices are down. Oil prices are down. And so I think -- and we've renegotiated some utility contracts, so I think that number could remain flat to slightly down. Advertising and selling, when we're 95% occupied, there's not a lot of need for that. I think when we get to Q2, we didn't do advertising in Q2 last year, so you won't see advertising this year. So that line will probably be flat. And whether we do advertising the balance of this year is yet to be determined. Other direct property tax costs were up 3.6% and then allocated overhead was down mainly because we used to have our annual sales conference in the first quarter, and we moved it into the third and fourth quarters of last year. And so last year was a double-up, and this year, we have the expense savings in Q1.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: For the acquisitions already completed this year, the annual contract rent is $1,165 and just lower than some of the previous years. Is there anything we can read into that number? Is it a reflection of the markets you're entering? Are any C of O deals in
componenttext: For the acquisitions already completed this year, the annual contract rent is $1,165 and just lower than some of the previous years. Is there anything we can read into that number? Is it a reflection of the markets you're entering? Are any C of O deals included in that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a function -- Todd, it really varies by market. You've got some of the properties are down in Texas. And I think we got one under contract in East Palo Alto that probably has a in-place rent of double what is down in Houston. So it just depends on wh
componenttext: It's a function -- Todd, it really varies by market. You've got some of the properties are down in Texas. And I think we got one under contract in East Palo Alto that probably has a in-place rent of double what is down in Houston. So it just depends on which markets for the properties that are in that quarter's acquisitions. We're not sitting here targeting we want to buy properties at $13 or $14 of in-place rents. It's really a function of do we want that property? Yes. And therefore, the rent makes sense, and so we'll buy it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe the sample size is small, and I'm looking at...
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe the sample size is small, and I'm looking at...

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just second, can you provide any color on the land lease buyout that you had in Q1?
componenttext: And then just second, can you provide any color on the land lease buyout that you had in Q1?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was a remnant transaction from the Shurgard merger in '06, and we had an option to acquire the land lease this year. And so it was a predetermined formula, and we exercised our option and closed on the transaction. It's a pretty good transaction f
componenttext: Yes, it was a remnant transaction from the Shurgard merger in '06, and we had an option to acquire the land lease this year. And so it was a predetermined formula, and we exercised our option and closed on the transaction. It's a pretty good transaction for us. Only $15 million, but it's a pretty good transaction.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this time, there are no further questions. I'll now return the call to management for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: At this time, there are no further questions. I'll now return the call to management for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: We appreciate everybody's interest in Public Storage and our first quarter -- wait, there is one more call there.
componenttext: We appreciate everybody's interest in Public Storage and our first quarter -- wait, there is one more call there.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: You do have a question from Dave Bragg of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: You do have a question from Dave Bragg of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just snuck in under the wire there. Just a bigger-picture question on supply for you. There's a lot of concern over this new supply that's emerging. But in light of your strong operating results, the question is, how much new supply does the industry need
componenttext: Just snuck in under the wire there. Just a bigger-picture question on supply for you. There's a lot of concern over this new supply that's emerging. But in light of your strong operating results, the question is, how much new supply does the industry need? It seems as though the supply is needed. And when you take a step back, Ron, and you look at 8 square feet per capita, does that seem like the right level going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, I think I've said that before. And you kind of -- you take the U.S. population, 7, 8 square feet per capita, normal population growth of 1% a year or you can take 50,000 facilities and 1% percent a year, that's 400 to 500 facilities per year. And th
componenttext: Dave, I think I've said that before. And you kind of -- you take the U.S. population, 7, 8 square feet per capita, normal population growth of 1% a year or you can take 50,000 facilities and 1% percent a year, that's 400 to 500 facilities per year. And that kind of keeps everything at 7 or 8 feet per capita. I will tell you as you go across the country, markets vary greatly between 2 and 3 square feet per capita and 12 and 15 square feet per capita. And obviously, the ones that have the higher square footage tend to have lower rate growth. If you ask me where development is -- will happen fastest, New York has been working on development programs for a while, so I think we'll see big uptick or meaningful uptick in supply in the New York area. And then across the country, it'll vary between in-fill markets and then outlying markets, where it's easier to get zoning, permitting and land is cheaper. But 400 to 500 properties a year kind of keeps things static, and we haven't had much development since '09. So we're kind of 4, 5 years behind in terms of the curve of new supply relative to organic population growth.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So the industry saw a significant secular shift in terms of growth of square feet per capita of maybe 3, 20 years ago, to 8 today. It seems like your thought is that we grow in line with -- growth in line with population. Growth would make sense th
componenttext: Right. So the industry saw a significant secular shift in terms of growth of square feet per capita of maybe 3, 20 years ago, to 8 today. It seems like your thought is that we grow in line with -- growth in line with population. Growth would make sense that we're -- not these results. The demand that we're seeing don't necessarily indicate that we need 9 or 10 square feet per capita.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I guess my point in mentioning the 9 or 10 or the -- like I know Austin's got over 11 feet per -- square feet per capita, and Austin's a pretty good market for us. So is the max 7? I don't think so. It varies by market. And could the country --
componenttext: Yes, well, I guess my point in mentioning the 9 or 10 or the -- like I know Austin's got over 11 feet per -- square feet per capita, and Austin's a pretty good market for us. So is the max 7? I don't think so. It varies by market. And could the country -- in the U.S., could we go to a 10 or 11 square foot per capita? I don't think that's unreasonable, given the trend toward movement to apartments, smaller homes, especially in markets like Manhattan and San Francisco and even parts of L.A. It's not impossible to get to a 10 or 11 per square foot. Is that going to happen? I can't say.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: One quick housekeeping one. You've referenced us to the 10-Q. Is that coming out today?
componenttext: One quick housekeeping one. You've referenced us to the 10-Q. Is that coming out today?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Probably next week, David.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Your next question is a follow-up from Smedes Rose of Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman here. Ron, I may have missed it in your opening comments because I dialed in late. But did you comment at all in terms of how you're going to replace the COO role? I know Shawn left in late March to be, I think, the CEO of some priva
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman here. Ron, I may have missed it in your opening comments because I dialed in late. But did you comment at all in terms of how you're going to replace the COO role? I know Shawn left in late March to be, I think, the CEO of some private educational company. Can you just talk a little bit about what those plans are?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, those plans have already been put in place. We have divided up the country and given responsibility to 3 outstanding executives that have been with Public Storage 15-plus years, and those 3 exceptional executives are now running operations.
componenttext: Yes, well, those plans have already been put in place. We have divided up the country and given responsibility to 3 outstanding executives that have been with Public Storage 15-plus years, and those 3 exceptional executives are now running operations.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: By committee?
componenttext: By committee?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: With a team.
componenttext: With a team.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, just the -- the 3 report effectively. And I ask it more so because I think the COO role has had some turnover over the last 5 or 6 years. I think Shawn may have been the third in that seat. So I didn't know if there was something structurally that w
componenttext: Well, just the -- the 3 report effectively. And I ask it more so because I think the COO role has had some turnover over the last 5 or 6 years. I think Shawn may have been the third in that seat. So I didn't know if there was something structurally that wasn't working. Just talk about what was -- what has -- and maybe there are just reasons why each of them left, but...

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: There are different reasons why each of them left, but you can ascribe it to my inability to hire a COO. So I'll just leave it at that. But the guys we have running the operations are longtime Public Storage execs that have grown up here in the operations
componenttext: There are different reasons why each of them left, but you can ascribe it to my inability to hire a COO. So I'll just leave it at that. But the guys we have running the operations are longtime Public Storage execs that have grown up here in the operations. And they're just -- well, you could tell by the results, they're doing an exceptional job.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And then what was the change in Chief Legal Officer beginning of the year? Was that a retirement? Or what transpired there?
componenttext: Right. And then what was the change in Chief Legal Officer beginning of the year? Was that a retirement? Or what transpired there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve retired. And actually, I don't know what Steve is doing, but he's retired and we brought on Lily Hughes.
componenttext: Yes, Steve retired. And actually, I don't know what Steve is doing, but he's retired and we brought on Lily Hughes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this time, there are no further questions. I'll now return the call to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: At this time, there are no further questions. I'll now return the call to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to Public Storage Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call [Operator Instructions]It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to Clem Teng, Vice President of Investor Relations.
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to Public Storage Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call [Operator Instructions]
It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to Clem Teng, Vice President of Investor Relations.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.I just want to remind you that all statements other than statements of historical facts, included in this conference call,
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
I just want to remind you that all statements other than statements of historical facts, included in this conference call, are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, July 30, 2015, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP and the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter, hitting on all cylinders in Europe and in the U.S. in our development pipeline and insurance.And so with that, let's open it up for questions.
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. We had another solid quarter, hitting on all cylinders in Europe and in the U.S. in our development pipeline and insurance.
And so with that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Steve Rose of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Steve Rose of Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about Shurgard, you've made this fairly large acquisition in the quarter and things seemed to be going very well there, having met with your team over there quite recently. How do think about your ownership there going forward, either
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about Shurgard, you've made this fairly large acquisition in the quarter and things seemed to be going very well there, having met with your team over there quite recently. How do think about your ownership there going forward, either in the public vehicle or in a private vehicle? Or is it just like the status quo?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, Steve, Shurgard Europe is relatively or modestly leveraged. They just did another EUR 300 million financing, so they have 600 million of term debt, average duration of about 9 years, sub-3%. And they will be turning generating about EUR 8
componenttext: Well, right now, Steve, Shurgard Europe is relatively or modestly leveraged. They just did another EUR 300 million financing, so they have 600 million of term debt, average duration of about 9 years, sub-3%. And they will be turning generating about EUR 80 to EUR 90 million of cash flow with really no requirements other than for growth. So in terms of doing IPO at this juncture, not sure what we would use the proceeds on since they funded all their acquisitions and they're sitting on EUR 70 million, EUR 80 million of cash at this juncture. Longer-term going forward, that will depend on market conditions, growth opportunities, those kinds of things.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I can just ask you, too, we keep saying a lot of media stories pop up about potential changes to Proposition 13, particularly related to commercial property versus residential. Just being out there and maybe me more in the weeds some of us are,
componenttext: Okay. Then I can just ask you, too, we keep saying a lot of media stories pop up about potential changes to Proposition 13, particularly related to commercial property versus residential. Just being out there and maybe me more in the weeds some of us are, do you have -- can you add any color to that in terms of what you think could happen there, if anything?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't tell you what might happen. But as far as we no, there's no pending legislation or bills in California. But I don't know at the moment what is being introduced. We haven't heard anything to give us concern at this juncture.
componenttext: Well, I can't tell you what might happen. But as far as we no, there's no pending legislation or bills in California. But I don't know at the moment what is being introduced. We haven't heard anything to give us concern at this juncture.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gaurav Mehta of Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gaurav Mehta of Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: You said Europe is strong, could you share operational occupancy and data for your open portfolio?
componenttext: You said Europe is strong, could you share operational occupancy and data for your open portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The same-store portfolio for Europe operated at 90.1% for the quarter, that's up from 84.9% last year, so a 6% increase in occupancy. We [indiscernible] down a 1.5 points. So revenue growth is about 4.5%, 4.6%. And at quarter end, the portfolio occu
componenttext: Sure. The same-store portfolio for Europe operated at 90.1% for the quarter, that's up from 84.9% last year, so a 6% increase in occupancy. We [indiscernible] down a 1.5 points. So revenue growth is about 4.5%, 4.6%. And at quarter end, the portfolio occupancy was 91.1%. All the markets across Europe were up in occupancy, year-over-year, the strongest being in Holland, which closed out the quarter at 87.5% to 76% versus last year, so a 15% growth. But if you recall, Holland has been a challenge for us over the last couple of years, so obviously, recovering and catching up with the rest of Europe.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff specter of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff specter of Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: If we could first focus on profit margins for the quarter in the U.S., we saw a nice improvement there. Can you discuss, I guess, the declines in advertising, selling expense and R&M? What we should expect maybe going forward, the next couple of quarters
componenttext: If we could first focus on profit margins for the quarter in the U.S., we saw a nice improvement there. Can you discuss, I guess, the declines in advertising, selling expense and R&M? What we should expect maybe going forward, the next couple of quarters or you been into '16?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. The advertising in the quarter primarily because we didn't do television advertising in the second quarter versus last year. What we did do about, I think, about $0.5 million dollars of advertising. We also spent a little less on the key sea
componenttext: This is John. The advertising in the quarter primarily because we didn't do television advertising in the second quarter versus last year. What we did do about, I think, about $0.5 million dollars of advertising. We also spent a little less on the key search terms on the Internet. I think that was down maybe couple of hundred thousand dollars there. Going forward, on the advertising, I would expect that it's probably going to be relatively flat Q3 and in Q4 because we'll probably go back onto television and those quarter similar to what we guess that last year. As for the R&M, I think it's down, but it's supposed to timing, I think, we're expecting for full year that are and will be relatively flat. So there should be a little bit of an uptick in the latter half of this year.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I know that each quarter we ask about occupancy in the business, your portfolio as a whole for self-storage keeps rising national levels. I mean, any new thoughts on full occupancy levels for your portfolio or even just in general, f
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I know that each quarter we ask about occupancy in the business, your portfolio as a whole for self-storage keeps rising national levels. I mean, any new thoughts on full occupancy levels for your portfolio or even just in general, for the self-storage industry?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is your question, what do we think we could possibly achieve, like what is the maximum occupancy levels, is that the question?
componenttext: Is your question, what do we think we could possibly achieve, like what is the maximum occupancy levels, is that the question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Basically, and of course, I would assume that's based on what you're seeing in your markets in general.
componenttext: Yes. Basically, and of course, I would assume that's based on what you're seeing in your markets in general.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have a couple of markets, our better performing markets in the quarter, like Denver and Portland, that had anything they're running about 97% almost 98% occupancy for the quarter. So you could say nationwide, we possibly achieve that, you have every ma
componenttext: We have a couple of markets, our better performing markets in the quarter, like Denver and Portland, that had anything they're running about 97% almost 98% occupancy for the quarter. So you could say nationwide, we possibly achieve that, you have every market taking on every cylinders. But more likely than not, there is some strong market, some average market and some weak markets, and so that might be tough to achieve on a national basis. For instance, right now, our D.C., Norfolk, Virginia markets are languishing a little bit the Midwest not nearly as strong as the West Coast. So to say, 2,000 portfolio operated 98% probably pretty hard. Having said that, we're about 96% today.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question on the supply front. I know the last time I saw your team, we discussed the competition for land, with apartments, anything new there on out competition for sites? Anything on the supply front to share with us, anything more r
componenttext: Okay. And then last question on the supply front. I know the last time I saw your team, we discussed the competition for land, with apartments, anything new there on out competition for sites? Anything on the supply front to share with us, anything more recent from June, July?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our main competitors for sites are multifamily, not really retail, some storage guys, once in a while we run into a storage guy competing for site, but it's mainly the multifamily. In terms of supply nationwide, we think it's picking up. If
componenttext: Well, I think our main competitors for sites are multifamily, not really retail, some storage guys, once in a while we run into a storage guy competing for site, but it's mainly the multifamily. In terms of supply nationwide, we think it's picking up. If you look at our development pipeline, as a percentage of our portfolio, it's about 2.7%. So maybe can extrapolate that in the industry and say, industry's growing at 2.7% as a whole. So that's 1,000 [ph] 1,200 properties. Growth is not uniform across the country though, it's occurring where you expect, Texas, Floridas, Carolinas. The positive of these market is that they have above-average population growth. It's not occurring to any San Francisco, L.A., Boston, Miami, the markets where it's much more challenging to get zoning and find sites to develop. Did that I address your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just I was wondering if you took a look at the smart stop portfolio. And if you did, why you chose not to be as aggressive on the dealers or competitors, just given where the cost of capital sits?
componenttext: Just I was wondering if you took a look at the smart stop portfolio. And if you did, why you chose not to be as aggressive on the dealers or competitors, just given where the cost of capital sits?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Todd, I just -- we did look at that portfolio, but I prefer not to answer that question.
componenttext: Todd, I just -- we did look at that portfolio, but I prefer not to answer that question.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just thinking about your marketing platform and your digital footprint, how does the scalability factor into your decision to buy properties? And does it factor into the equation at all for PSA when you're looking to make new investments?
componenttext: Okay. And just thinking about your marketing platform and your digital footprint, how does the scalability factor into your decision to buy properties? And does it factor into the equation at all for PSA when you're looking to make new investments?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, scale does. We look to increase our market share in our key markets where we operate. So if you look at a market like Florida, Miami, Fort Lauderdale, over the past 5, 8 years, we've grown from about a 14% market share to 28%, 25%, 28% ma
componenttext: Well, certainly, scale does. We look to increase our market share in our key markets where we operate. So if you look at a market like Florida, Miami, Fort Lauderdale, over the past 5, 8 years, we've grown from about a 14% market share to 28%, 25%, 28% market share. The same is happening in market like Minnesota, Seattle, certainly in Dallas and you still we're rebuilding our market shares increasing there. So we're very much focus our acquisitions in our development program on expanding our platform in the key markets where we operate. And so that certainly is in our decision in terms of when you look at our portfolio liked the ones you just mentioned, there's a lot of tertiary markets there where we have the product and in a number of cases, we have no interest in having any product so it doesn't do much for the platform. Certainly, scale in markets is very important. John can touch  on the marketing side of it and the pricing side. But the scale in terms of operating efficiency, our managerial talent, brand awareness, here in L.A., we often have analysts come through and say, did you guys have ever worked here in L.A. and we are here in L.A. We dominate the market, there's 200 plus property. So that's great for brand awareness and in television, advertising and marketing.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. That's helpful just a follow-up and then on the selling and advertising expense, it was down nearly 10%, but it was still about $5.5 million in the quarter. And just thinking about where occupancy is, why is that not down more? I would think th
componenttext: Yes, okay. That's helpful just a follow-up and then on the selling and advertising expense, it was down nearly 10%, but it was still about $5.5 million in the quarter. And just thinking about where occupancy is, why is that not down more? I would think that you could pair that back a bit more.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're doing everything we can to pair it back. Even though our occupancies remain high, we still had over 200,000 tenants move-out during the quarter. So we still have to advertise to replace these tenants and maintain the occupancy level. So if people st
componenttext: We're doing everything we can to pair it back. Even though our occupancies remain high, we still had over 200,000 tenants move-out during the quarter. So we still have to advertise to replace these tenants and maintain the occupancy level. So if people stop moving out, I can guarantee, we will cut down that advertising cost quite a bit.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Follow-up on that previous question. As you're pushing 96% -- well, I guess, you hit 96% in July, it sounded like, what point do you think, number 1, is sufficiently high enough? And I know you've been pushing this already, but maybe push harder. When is
componenttext: Follow-up on that previous question. As you're pushing 96% -- well, I guess, you hit 96% in July, it sounded like, what point do you think, number 1, is sufficiently high enough? And I know you've been pushing this already, but maybe push harder. When is that equation favor pushing just give occupancies higher?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The problem when that happens when you start pushing the rate too high is you will get a tenant that you'll probably have to continue to provide the dollar special discount, and/or you will get a tenant that will not be a very long-term tenant. So it's no
componenttext: The problem when that happens when you start pushing the rate too high is you will get a tenant that you'll probably have to continue to provide the dollar special discount, and/or you will get a tenant that will not be a very long-term tenant. So it's not necessarily -- the game is not one on the move-in rate. The game is one on getting the tenant that stays long and it gets because very sticky to rate increases. So although we are pushing rate, because we get more aggressive, absolutely, when we lose occupancy and we would get a tenant that would not stay as long and that's not in our strategy.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ki,  to follow on that for the quarter percentage of customers greater than 1 year was up 60 basis points to 55.9%, up from 55.3%. So if you had a chart in front in the last 3 years, you'd see each quarter and year-over-year, we're moving that percentage
componenttext: Ki,  to follow on that for the quarter percentage of customers greater than 1 year was up 60 basis points to 55.9%, up from 55.3%. So if you had a chart in front in the last 3 years, you'd see each quarter and year-over-year, we're moving that percentage of customers greater than 1 year up. And that really goes to John's comment in terms of building that base of stable customers that are somewhat of a sticky annuity.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the second question, when you're talking to, which I'm assuming you are in a lot fo bigger operators other outside 5 public companies now, how has the conversations evolved in terms of their willingness to sell, kind of the bid aspect, what they want
componenttext: And the second question, when you're talking to, which I'm assuming you are in a lot fo bigger operators other outside 5 public companies now, how has the conversations evolved in terms of their willingness to sell, kind of the bid aspect, what they want versus what you're willing to pay for assets, has that gone -- if I stick to it more feasible to do bigger deals or still a tough as before?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, nearly the dynamic in the larger portfolios is not per se a question of price at this juncture, it's more a question of ownership dynamics and that can be families, that can be partners, that can be dead other alternatives to sell it just simply ref
componenttext: Well, nearly the dynamic in the larger portfolios is not per se a question of price at this juncture, it's more a question of ownership dynamics and that can be families, that can be partners, that can be dead other alternatives to sell it just simply refinancing because it's not hard to refinance a full stable portfolio at this juncture. So there's a lot of alternatives to the more established operators besides just selling and to a price. There's other dynamics within the ownership going on besides this, do you want to sell or do you not want to sell.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you could comment on what participation rate was at the end of the quarter? And then also, if there's any update you can provide on any of the ongoing lawsuit and legal fees, whether that's pertaining to tenant insurance or other matter
componenttext: I just wondered if you could comment on what participation rate was at the end of the quarter? And then also, if there's any update you can provide on any of the ongoing lawsuit and legal fees, whether that's pertaining to tenant insurance or other matters that may have been resolved that you could comment on?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So your first question was how much was your question how much of the portfolio is covered by insurance or customer base or what the penetration rates for the new customers?
componenttext: Okay. So your first question was how much was your question how much of the portfolio is covered by insurance or customer base or what the penetration rates for the new customers?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, part of the existing portfolio.
componenttext: Well, part of the existing portfolio.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: George, approximately 66% to 68% of our tenants have the tenant -- participate in the tenant reinsurance program that is offered at our properties. In terms of the G&A this past quarter, G&A was up $5.5 million, and about $3.2 million of that related to i
componenttext: George, approximately 66% to 68% of our tenants have the tenant -- participate in the tenant reinsurance program that is offered at our properties. In terms of the G&A this past quarter, G&A was up $5.5 million, and about $3.2 million of that related to increased legal costs and it's for various matters out there. And we're not going to go through what those factors are on this call.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz of UBS.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz of UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Nussbaum with Jeremy. Can you talk a little bit about the topic of move ins versus moveouts? What was the percentage increase or decrease year-over-year for each of those stats in Q2?
componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum with Jeremy. Can you talk a little bit about the topic of move ins versus moveouts? What was the percentage increase or decrease year-over-year for each of those stats in Q2?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. So the move-in, we're up -- excuse me, we're down about 1%, the move in rate, the rental rate that they came in was up about 8% for the quarter. On the moveouts, the moveouts were about flat year-over-year. The rate, the contract rate or the
componenttext: This is John. So the move-in, we're up -- excuse me, we're down about 1%, the move in rate, the rental rate that they came in was up about 8% for the quarter. On the moveouts, the moveouts were about flat year-over-year. The rate, the contract rate or the rental rates that they retained was up about 4.5%. Does that answer your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. I asked this question extra space as well. I'm trying to think of how should we all be thinking about the fact that move ins are down year-over-year yet the industry is enjoying such significant occupancy and pricing pressure if we beat cons
componenttext: Yes, it does. I asked this question extra space as well. I'm trying to think of how should we all be thinking about the fact that move ins are down year-over-year yet the industry is enjoying such significant occupancy and pricing pressure if we beat considering all of that number.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't speak about other peoples moveins volumes. And what I can tell you with respect to ours, with our occupancy as far as there are spread being rent higher than last year, we have less inventory to sell. So notwithstanding the fact that our abso
componenttext: Yes, I can't speak about other peoples moveins volumes. And what I can tell you with respect to ours, with our occupancy as far as there are spread being rent higher than last year, we have less inventory to sell. So notwithstanding the fact that our absolute numbers, our move-in volume is down, the velocity of move ins, the move-in relative to what we have to sell as a percentage is up quite a bit. So I mean, if you took to an extreme when we're 100% occupied, we would have no move-in, right? So the closer we get to being highly 100% occupied, it's very difficult to get moving volumes to a year-over-year basis to increase. So we're quite comfortable with the move-ins. We're still getting a lot of -- unfortunately, we're getting a lot of the money to our system the demand, the quality of the websites, website both mobile and desktop are still way up. Part of our problem is, is that we have, we're running to a capacity issue in terms of inventory.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ross, for the quarter, even though the move-in volume was down about 2,000 customers and the moveouts were about flat, we still had 21,800 net customers for the quarter. Now that's less than last year where we had 24,000 customers. But to John's point, we
componenttext: Ross, for the quarter, even though the move-in volume was down about 2,000 customers and the moveouts were about flat, we still had 21,800 net customers for the quarter. Now that's less than last year where we had 24,000 customers. But to John's point, we still had on that 21,000 more people move-in to move-out during the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ron, strategically, you talked a little bit about your IPO in the works. You know and I talked in the past about PS Business Parks. And what you were talking earlier I was just pointing up relative chart of PSA versus PSP over. Basically, any time frame y
componenttext: Ron, strategically, you talked a little bit about your IPO in the works. You know and I talked in the past about PS Business Parks. And what you were talking earlier I was just pointing up relative chart of PSA versus PSP over. Basically, any time frame you want to put up from year-to-date to 20 years. And PAS has been taking PSB's butt from a relative share price performance. I guess, what's it's going to take ultimately to spend those shares off to shareholders and let your existing shareholders say if they want to invest in self-storage, let them purely invest self-storage and if they like PSB, they can hold their shares.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Ross, we'll step a couple of things. First of all, if you -- self-storage is completely different business than flex industrial. So that's 1. 2, PSB's about 4% of our NOI price value, whatever you want to call it. 3, if for us to change our attitude
componenttext: Well, Ross, we'll step a couple of things. First of all, if you -- self-storage is completely different business than flex industrial. So that's 1. 2, PSB's about 4% of our NOI price value, whatever you want to call it. 3, if for us to change our attitude on doing anything with PSB in terms of spinning of the setting there will be a need change in the tax law that's we will not pay any taxes on that because most of our interest are held in OP units, which have, frankly, a de minimis tax basis. And so whatever we did with it, for the most part, will be purely taxable income and end up requiring a distribution.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: One quick one for me. Obviously, it looks like 10 assets in the same-store pool. Can you just talk about what's going on with those? And what kind of costs you're looking at to get them back online just given yourself in short?
componenttext: One quick one for me. Obviously, it looks like 10 assets in the same-store pool. Can you just talk about what's going on with those? And what kind of costs you're looking at to get them back online just given yourself in short?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, they were pretty severe weather in Houston in Q2, they're pretty damaged and so we took them out of the same-store pool because they will require extensive repairs. And on tenant insurance business, we had about $800,000 additional cost for estimate
componenttext: Well, they were pretty severe weather in Houston in Q2, they're pretty damaged and so we took them out of the same-store pool because they will require extensive repairs. And on tenant insurance business, we had about $800,000 additional cost for estimated claims related to those properties. And in terms of our final estimate of how much is going to cost to repair, we don't have that, it's still on the process. My guess is it will be a couple of million dollars.

componenttext: We saw on that Shurgard issued a bond to fund their Netherlands acquisition. And Ron, you noted, they're generating free cash flow. But just as a reminder, is there a commitment in place for Public Storage to provide capital to Shurgard? Just get a reminder what the commitment is, if any.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Shurgard operates as a stand-alone entity. We own 49% of it. A large pension fund owns 51% of it, the other 51% in Shurgard is taken us quite a while to get here, but Shurgard is self funding, and as I noted. It issued the bond to EUR 600 million bond
componenttext: No. Shurgard operates as a stand-alone entity. We own 49% of it. A large pension fund owns 51% of it, the other 51% in Shurgard is taken us quite a while to get here, but Shurgard is self funding, and as I noted. It issued the bond to EUR 600 million bond without any credit support from either of the 2 shareholders.

componenttext: But nothing in writing to say, you would commit equity to a large acquisition or anything like that?

componenttext: No.

componenttext: Okay. And then just to look at an update on your current expectations, you're same-store pool continues to generate accelerating fundamentals at this point in the cycle, any updated thoughts on what it takes to, say, stabilized new development and the deals in anything, that you've revised if anything internally as we enter August here?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, internally, we continued to use our historical underwriting assumptions internally of about 3 years for the standard size property. If it's above average size, I believe, we used 4 years. So for a 2,000 plus unit property, we use of 4-year stabiliza
componenttext: Well, internally, we continued to use our historical underwriting assumptions internally of about 3 years for the standard size property. If it's above average size, I believe, we used 4 years. So for a 2,000 plus unit property, we use of 4-year stabilization period. The nice thing is we're exceeding those by quite a bit. We opened a new facility here in Glendale, about 2,000 units at the end of April and it's already half, 50% occupied in about 2 months. So that's quite incredible. That's a combination of -- it's a great product, the marketing team, the Internet marketing team, highlighting that facility, the pricing team, pricing it to sell and then, of course, operational execution at the unit level.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sticking with development for a second. It looks like right now, the pipeline is $450 million to $500 million for development and expansion. 2 questions. One, does it feel like over the near-term that's a good run rate for the size of the pipeline? And th
componenttext: Sticking with development for a second. It looks like right now, the pipeline is $450 million to $500 million for development and expansion. 2 questions. One, does it feel like over the near-term that's a good run rate for the size of the pipeline? And then, secondly, if you didn't start anything new, how long does it take you to complete those developments to bring them online?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think, the team is -- got their track shoes on going around the track about as fast as they can with respect to the development team, their doing a great job. And keep in mind in terms of the development pipeline, you've got stuff delivery, so we
componenttext: Mike, I think, the team is -- got their track shoes on going around the track about as fast as they can with respect to the development team, their doing a great job. And keep in mind in terms of the development pipeline, you've got stuff delivery, so we got product like the Glendale property delivered in Q2. So that comes out of the pipeline and so you've got to back fill that and to run in place of $500 million or $480 million. So there's a continuous in out process on that pipeline of deliveries and new projects coming into it. So I would anticipate much more that number going much above $500 million, certainly not within the next 6 to 12 months. In terms of what we've got under construction and how long, it will be pretty much third, fourth quarter of '16 before that's all built in out and operating and then you configure 2 years after that before stabilized. So we're thinking '18 before what we're working on now before it gets the stabilized.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
