          Okay, great. And then I know that each quarter we ask about occupancy in the business. Your portfolio as a whole for all self-storage keeps rising at national levels. I mean, any new thoughts on full occupancy levels for your portfolio or even just in general for the self-storage industry?

componenttext:

          Yes, basically. And of course, I would assume that's based on what you're seeing in your markets in general.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes. We have a couple of markets, our better performing markets in the quarter, like Denver and Portland, that had -- I think they're running at about 97%, almost 98% occupancy for the quarter. So you could say nationwide, we possibly achie
componenttext:
:  
          Yes. We have a couple of markets, our better performing markets in the quarter, like Denver and Portland, that had -- I think they're running at about 97%, almost 98% occupancy for the quarter. So you could say nationwide, we possibly achieved that. Well, yes, every market was hitting on all cylinders. But more likely than not, there's some strong markets, some average markets and some weak markets. And so that might be tough to achieve on a national basis. For instance, right now, our D.C., Norfolk, Virginia markets are languishing a little bit. The Midwest, not nearly as strong as the West Coast. So to say a 2,000 portfolio operating at 98%, probably pretty hard. Having said that, we're about 96% today.

componenttext:

          Okay. And then last question on the supply front. I know the last time I saw your team, we discussed the competition for land with apartments. Anything new there on competition for sites? Anything on the supply front to share with us? Anything more recent from June, July?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext:

          Well, I think our main competitors for sites are multifamily, not really retail, some storage guys, although...

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Once in a while.
componenttext: Once in a while.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  Once in awhile, we run into a storage guy competing for a site, but it's mainly the multifamily. In terms of supply nationwide, we think it's picking up. If you look at our development pipeline as a percentage of our portfolio, it's about 2.7%. So ma
componenttext:
:  
Once in awhile, we run into a storage guy competing for a site, but it's mainly the multifamily. In terms of supply nationwide, we think it's picking up. If you look at our development pipeline as a percentage of our portfolio, it's about 2.7%. So maybe you can extrapolate that to industry and say the industry is growing at 2.7% as a whole. So that's 1,000, 1,200 properties. Growth is not uniform across the country though. It's occurring where you would expect, Texas, Florida, the Carolinas. The positive of those markets is they have above-average population growth. It's not occurring to any significant degree in San Francisco, L.A., Boston, Miami, the markets where it's much more challenging to get zoning and find sites to develop. Did that address your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes.
componenttext:
:  
          Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Okay. And just in thinking about your marketing platform and your digital footprint, how does the scalability factor into your decision to buy properties? And does it factor into the equation at all for PSA when you're looking to make new i
componenttext:
:  
          Okay. And just in thinking about your marketing platform and your digital footprint, how does the scalability factor into your decision to buy properties? And does it factor into the equation at all for PSA when you're looking to make new investments?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, certainly, scale does. We look to increase our market share in our key markets where we operate. So if you look at a market like Florida, Miami, Fort Lauderdale over the past 5, 8 years, we've grown from about a 14% market share to 28
componenttext:
:  
          Well, certainly, scale does. We look to increase our market share in our key markets where we operate. So if you look at a market like Florida, Miami, Fort Lauderdale over the past 5, 8 years, we've grown from about a 14% market share to 28% -- 25%, 28% market share. The same is happening in markets like Minnesota, Seattle, certainly in Dallas and Houston where we're building, our market shares is increasing there. So we very much focus our acquisitions and our development program on expanding our platform in the key markets where we operate. And so that certainly enters in our decision in terms of when you look at our portfolio like the one you just mentioned, there's a lot of tertiary markets there where we have no product. And in a number of cases, we have no interest in having any product, so it doesn't do much for the platform. Certainly, scale in markets is very important. John can touch on the marketing side of it and the pricing side. But the scale in terms of operating efficiency, managerial talent, brand awareness -- here in L.A., we often have analysts come through and say, "You guys are everywhere here in L.A." And we are here everywhere in L.A. We dominate the market. There's 200-plus properties. So that's great for brand awareness and in television, advertising and marketing. Do you want to add anything?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  Yes, I don't have anything else to add.
componenttext:
:  
Yes, I don't have anything else to add.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  That's your question?
componenttext:

That's your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, that's helpful. Just a follow-up then on the selling and advertising expense. It was down nearly 10% but it was still about $5.5 million in the quarter. And just in thinking about where occupancy is, why is that not down more? I would
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, that's helpful. Just a follow-up then on the selling and advertising expense. It was down nearly 10% but it was still about $5.5 million in the quarter. And just in thinking about where occupancy is, why is that not down more? I would think that you could pare that back a bit more.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            We're doing everything we can to pare it back. Even though our occupancies remain high, we still had over 200,000 tenants move out during the quarter. So we still have to advertise to replace those tenants and maintain the occupancy level.
componenttext:
:  
          We're doing everything we can to pare it back. Even though our occupancies remain high, we still had over 200,000 tenants move out during the quarter. So we still have to advertise to replace those tenants and maintain the occupancy level. So if people stop moving out, I can guarantee you, we'll cut down that advertising cost quite a bit.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

          Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Just a follow-up on that previous question. As you're pushing 96% -- well, I guess, you hit 96% in July, it sounded like, at what point do you think where rate is sufficiently high enough? And I know you've been pushing rates already, but m
componenttext:
:  
          Just a follow-up on that previous question. As you're pushing 96% -- well, I guess, you hit 96% in July, it sounded like, at what point do you think where rate is sufficiently high enough? And I know you've been pushing rates already, but maybe push harder. When is that equation start to favor pushing the rate level much more than just keeping occupancies higher?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            The problem that happens when you start pushing rate too high is you will get a tenant that you'll probably have to continue to provide the dollar special discount and/or you will get a tenant that will not be a very long-term tenant. So it
componenttext:
:  
          The problem that happens when you start pushing rate too high is you will get a tenant that you'll probably have to continue to provide the dollar special discount and/or you will get a tenant that will not be a very long-term tenant. So it's not necessarily -- the game is not won on the move-in rate. The game is won on getting the tenant that stays long and gets -- becomes very sticky to rate increases. So although we are pushing rate, could we get more aggressive? Absolutely. But we'd lose occupancy and we would get a tenant that would not stay as long, and that's not in our strategy.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Ki, to follow on, on that for the quarter percentage of customers greater than 1 year was up 60 basis points to 55.9%, up from 55.3%. So if you had a chart in front you, the last 3 years, you'd see each quarter and year-over-year, we're mov
componenttext:
:  
          Ki, to follow on, on that for the quarter percentage of customers greater than 1 year was up 60 basis points to 55.9%, up from 55.3%. So if you had a chart in front you, the last 3 years, you'd see each quarter and year-over-year, we're moving that percentage of customers greater than 1 year up. And that really goes to John's comment in terms of building that base of stable customers that are somewhat of a sticky annuity.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            And the second question, when you're talking to, which I'm assuming you are, a lot of bigger operators out there outside the kind of 5 public companies now, how have the conversations evolved in terms of their willingness to sell, kind of t
componenttext:
:  
          And the second question, when you're talking to, which I'm assuming you are, a lot of bigger operators out there outside the kind of 5 public companies now, how have the conversations evolved in terms of their willingness to sell, kind of the bid-ask spread between what they want versus what you're willing to pay for assets. Has that gotten, if I had to put a measuring stick to it, more feasible to do bigger deals? Or it's still tough as before?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, usually, the dynamic in the larger portfolios is not per se a question of price at this juncture. It's more a question of ownership dynamics. And that can be families, that can be partners, that can be debt, other alternatives to sell
componenttext:
:  
          Well, usually, the dynamic in the larger portfolios is not per se a question of price at this juncture. It's more a question of ownership dynamics. And that can be families, that can be partners, that can be debt, other alternatives to selling, just simply refinancing because it's not hard to refinance a full stable portfolio at this juncture. So there's a lot of alternatives to the more established operators besides just selling and/or price. They have -- there's other dynamics within the ownership going on besides just do you want to sell or do you not want to sell.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, this is John. So the move-ins, we're up -- we're down -- excuse me, down about 1%, the move in rate. The rate --- the rental rate that they came in at was up about 8% for the quarter. On the move-outs, the move-outs, the move-outs were
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, this is John. So the move-ins, we're up -- we're down -- excuse me, down about 1%, the move in rate. The rate --- the rental rate that they came in at was up about 8% for the quarter. On the move-outs, the move-outs, the move-outs were about flat year-over-year. The rate, the contract rate or the rental rate that they're repaying was up about 4.5%. Does that answer your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, it does. I mean, I asked this question of extra space as well. I'm trying to think of how should we all be thinking about the fact that move-ins are down year-over-year, yet the industry is enjoying such significant occupancy and prici
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, it does. I mean, I asked this question of extra space as well. I'm trying to think of how should we all be thinking about the fact that move-ins are down year-over-year, yet the industry is enjoying such significant occupancy and pricing pressure? Should we be concerned at all about that number?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, I can't speak about other people's move-in volumes and whether they're up or down. But what I could tell you with respect to ours, with our occupancies as high as they are and our occupancy spread being higher than last year, we have l
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, I can't speak about other people's move-in volumes and whether they're up or down. But what I could tell you with respect to ours, with our occupancies as high as they are and our occupancy spread being higher than last year, we have less inventory to sell. So notwithstanding the fact that our absolute -- in the absolute numbers, our move-in volume is down. The velocity of move-ins, the move-ins relative to what we have to sell as a percentage is up quite a bit. So I mean, we can -- I mean, if you took it to an extreme and we were 100% occupied, we would have no move-ins, right? So the closer we get to being highly 100% occupied, it's very difficult to get move-in volumes to -- on a year-over-year basis to increase. So we're quite comfortable with the move-ins. We're still getting a lot of -- unfortunately, we're getting a lot of demand into our system. The demand, the call volumes, the hits to our websites -- our website, both mobile and desktop, are still way up. Part of our problem is, is that we have -- we're running to a capacity issue in terms of inventory.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  Ross, for the quarter, even though the move-in volume was down about 2,000 customers and the move-outs were about flat, we still had 21,800 net customers for the quarter. Now that's less than last year when we had 24,000 net customers. But to John's
componenttext:
:  
Ross, for the quarter, even though the move-in volume was down about 2,000 customers and the move-outs were about flat, we still had 21,800 net customers for the quarter. Now that's less than last year when we had 24,000 net customers. But to John's point, we still had on that 21,000 more people move-in than move-out during the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Got it, okay. Ron, look, you -- strategically, you talked a little about Shurgard Europe and an IPO isn't in the works. You and I have talked in the past about PS Business Parks. And what you were talking earlier -- I was just pulling up a
componenttext:
:  
          Got it, okay. Ron, look, you -- strategically, you talked a little about Shurgard Europe and an IPO isn't in the works. You and I have talked in the past about PS Business Parks. And what you were talking earlier -- I was just pulling up a relative chart of PSA versus PSB over basically any time frame you want to put up from year-to-date to 20 years. And PSA has been kicking PSB's butt from a relative share price performance. I guess, what's it going to take ultimately to spin those shares off to shareholders and let your existing shareholders say if they want to be invested in self-storage, let them purely invest in self-storage; and if they like PSB, they can hold their shares.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, Ross, step back a couple of things. First of all, if you -- self-storage is a completely different business than flex, industrial. So that's one. Two, PSB's about 4% of our NOI, price value, whatever you want to call it. Three, if --
componenttext:
:  
          Well, Ross, step back a couple of things. First of all, if you -- self-storage is a completely different business than flex, industrial. So that's one. Two, PSB's about 4% of our NOI, price value, whatever you want to call it. Three, if -- for us to change our attitude on doing anything with PSB in terms of spinning off or selling it, there will be a -- need to be a change in the tax law such that we would not pay any taxes on that because most of our interests are held in OP units, which have, quite frankly, a de minimis tax basis. And so whatever we did with it would, for the most part, be purely taxable income and end up requiring a distribution.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, that last point is interesting. Okay, I think Jeremy's got a question.
componenttext: Okay. Yes, that last point is interesting. Okay, I think Jeremy's got a question.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one quick one for me. Obviously, you took out looks like 10 Houston assets on the same-store pool. Can you just talk about what's going on with those? And what kind of costs you're looking at to get them back online just given that you self-insure?
componenttext: Just one quick one for me. Obviously, you took out looks like 10 Houston assets on the same-store pool. Can you just talk about what's going on with those? And what kind of costs you're looking at to get them back online just given that you self-insure?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, they were flooded. There was some pretty severe weather in Houston in the Q2. They were pretty damaged, and so we took them out of the same-store pool because they will require extensive repairs. And on a tenant insurance business, we
componenttext:
:  
          Well, they were flooded. There was some pretty severe weather in Houston in the Q2. They were pretty damaged, and so we took them out of the same-store pool because they will require extensive repairs. And on a tenant insurance business, we had about $800,000 additional cost for estimated claims related to those properties. And in terms of our final estimate of how much it's going to cost to repair, we don't have that. That's still on a process. My guess is it will be a couple million dollars.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            No. Shurgard operates as a stand-alone entity. We own 49% of it. A large pension fund owns 51% of it, the other 51% in Shurgard. It's taken us quite a while to get here, but Shurgard is self-funding, and as I noted. And it issued the bond,
componenttext:
:  
          No. Shurgard operates as a stand-alone entity. We own 49% of it. A large pension fund owns 51% of it, the other 51% in Shurgard. It's taken us quite a while to get here, but Shurgard is self-funding, and as I noted. And it issued the bond, the EUR 600 million bond without any credit support from either of the 2 shareholders.

Any updated thoughts on what it takes to, say, stabilize new development and C/O deals, anything that you've revised if anything internally as we enter August here?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, internally, we continue to use our historical underwriting assumptions generally about 3 years for a standard-sized property. If it's above-average size, say, like the Gerard property, I believe we used 4 years. So for a 2,000-plus un
componenttext:
:  
          Well, internally, we continue to use our historical underwriting assumptions generally about 3 years for a standard-sized property. If it's above-average size, say, like the Gerard property, I believe we used 4 years. So for a 2,000-plus unit property, we use a 4-year stabilization period. The nice thing is we're exceeding those by quite a bit. We opened a new facility here in Glendale, about 2,000 units at the end of April. And it's already half, 50% occupied in about 2 months. So that's quite incredible. That's a combination of it's a great product, the marketing team, the Internet marketing team highlighting that facility, the pricing team pricing it to sell and then, of course, operational execution at the unit level.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Sticking with development for a second. It looks like right now, the pipeline is $450 million to $500 million for development and expansion. Two questions. One, does it feel like over the near-term that's a good run rate for the size of the
componenttext:
:  
          Sticking with development for a second. It looks like right now, the pipeline is $450 million to $500 million for development and expansion. Two questions. One, does it feel like over the near-term that's a good run rate for the size of the pipeline? And then secondly, if you didn't start anything new, how long does it take you to complete those developments and bring them online?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Mike, I think we're -- the team has got their track shoes on and they're going around the track about as fast as they can. With respect to the development team, they're doing a great job. And keep in mind, in terms of the development pipeli
componenttext:
:  
          Mike, I think we're -- the team has got their track shoes on and they're going around the track about as fast as they can. With respect to the development team, they're doing a great job. And keep in mind, in terms of the development pipeline, you've got stuff delivering, right? So we've got product, right? The Glendale property delivered in Q2. So that comes out of the pipeline. And so you've got to backfill that just to kind of run in place at $500 million or $480 million. So there's a continuous in, out process on that pipeline of deliveries and in new projects coming into it. So I wouldn't anticipate much more -- that number going much above $500 million, certainly not within the next 6 to 12 months. In terms of what we've got under construction and how long, it will be pretty much third, fourth quarter of '16 before that's all built in out of the ground and operating and then you configure, 2 years after that before it's stabilized. So you're thinking '18 before what we're working on now gets stabilized.

:  
          John, as you just kind of parsed through the rent data, I guess, Ki kind of hit on my question. But I'm just trying to think if you see anything kind of in the data as it relates to rent increases, pushback from customers, anything kind of by region, maybe by demographic profile of the center, just anything that you could sort of share with us about kind of the elasticity of demand here.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes. Steve, we do look at that. We look at it by market, by demographics. We aren't seeing anything different than what we saw last year. So they're behaving the same for the most part. So we're continuing to send out those increases, just
componenttext:
:  
          Yes. Steve, we do look at that. We look at it by market, by demographics. We aren't seeing anything different than what we saw last year. So they're behaving the same for the most part. So we're continuing to send out those increases, just the same strategy as we have last year. We probably year-to-date have sent out about 5% more increases and the percentage increase is about the same as last year, which is about 9% to 10%.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Okay. And then, Ron, I know we've talked a little bit about sort of your funding strategy and your maybe desire to expand your capital sources and you are sort of contemplating the unsecured bond market. Just kind of what's the status at to
componenttext:
:  
          Okay. And then, Ron, I know we've talked a little bit about sort of your funding strategy and your maybe desire to expand your capital sources and you are sort of contemplating the unsecured bond market. Just kind of what's the status at today? I realized you're largely self-funding unless maybe something large comes along. But is there any even thought process to doing some longer-dated debt? And would you even have an opportunity to maybe call in some of the preferreds and do kind of a swap there?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Steve, we are certainly looking at that. So I wouldn't be surprised if before the year is done that we haven't tapped into some form of debt. I mentioned the last time, we've been looking at private placement as well as public debt. We've l
componenttext:
:  
          Steve, we are certainly looking at that. So I wouldn't be surprised if before the year is done that we haven't tapped into some form of debt. I mentioned the last time, we've been looking at private placement as well as public debt. We've looked at various maturity levels, which are certainly long-dated maturities also. And we do have a few series of preferred stock. One becomes callable in the fourth quarter of this year and I think we have 2 larger series that become callable next year. So it's definitely on in my mind, and I think you might see something happen before the end of the year.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext:

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            It's Michael Bilerman. Ron, I want to just come back on development. So 2.7% outstanding today relative to your stock and I think you commented that use that as a good proxy for the rest of the industry. And I guess, from a delivery standpo
componenttext:
:  
          It's Michael Bilerman. Ron, I want to just come back on development. So 2.7% outstanding today relative to your stock and I think you commented that use that as a good proxy for the rest of the industry. And I guess, from a delivery standpoint, I think you said most of what's under development today is going to deliver by the end of 2016? Or do you think some of that gets pushed from a completion standpoint into '17?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            No. Mike, I think most of what -- and the projects that I kind of used, the 60 properties, either under construction, about to start construction or we're pretty close to getting the deal tied down, I would anticipate that those would be co
componenttext:
:  
          No. Mike, I think most of what -- and the projects that I kind of used, the 60 properties, either under construction, about to start construction or we're pretty close to getting the deal tied down, I would anticipate that those would be constructed by the end of 2016. A good chunk, balance of this year, first half next year, but it will dribble out through 2016. So if you take that 60 properties, we're 5% of the industry, say, so that's about 1,200 properties nationwide, right, 100 million to 120 million square feet. It's not occurring at all uniformly, though, across the country. It's -- where we're developing, where we see other people developing the most, are markets where you would expect, Texas, Florida, Arizona. We're not developing anything in the Midwest, but there are stuff going on there. Where is development not occurring or it's de minimis? Los Angeles, San Francisco, downtown Seattle, downtown Miami, Boston, where it's very challenging to get sites. You're competing with the high-rise residential guys where there's simply not available -- land available to build self-storage. So it's not uniform across the country. But if you then take our portfolio, our development as a percentage of our portfolio, where we are in the industry, 2.5%, 3% industry expansion doesn't sound unreasonable. That compares with kind of the natural growth rate, which I've talked about on previous calls, of U.S. population growth, which is somewhere between 0.8% and 1% across the country. Again, population growth is not uniform. It's higher on markets like Texas, Florida, Arizona. So maybe the product coming on there can be absorbed by the above-average population growth.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Do you feel like the rest of the industry is accelerating development faster than you as more capital comes into the system and they see the good fundamentals? And so while you may be developing 2.7% of your base, as we move over the next 1
componenttext:
:  
          Do you feel like the rest of the industry is accelerating development faster than you as more capital comes into the system and they see the good fundamentals? And so while you may be developing 2.7% of your base, as we move over the next 12 months, that 2.7% is going to -- effectively doubled in the last 12 months, so could it double again and rise to 5% of the stock as we go into '17 and '18?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            I don't want to rule out any possibilities. Certainly, the opportunity for a developer to do what is referred to as the C/O deals, where pretty much the other public companies are offering to buy properties, newly developed, takeaway the fi
componenttext:
:  
          I don't want to rule out any possibilities. Certainly, the opportunity for a developer to do what is referred to as the C/O deals, where pretty much the other public companies are offering to buy properties, newly developed, takeaway the fill-up risk, the operational risk and from what we've observed, pay close to retail prices on that, that's certainly a very, very strong incentive if you're a local or regional developer for you to build and sell product into the public market via the C/O deals. What that does to the volume, I don't know. And is our percentage reflective of the industry? Well, maybe -- we started development a couple of years ago, so maybe we're a little ahead of the curve. But our feeling here, our observation is certainly development is accelerating. Most regional and local operators that we talk to are all developing, whether it's 1 project or 5, everyone -- a lot of people are developing product.

componenttext:

          150%. It varies, Jordan. I mean, I don't have the information to say what. We just -- we can look at what we're building for per foot approximately and see some of these deals and go, "Okay, that's about 150% to 200% of what we're building for in those markets."

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, interesting. Okay. And say, I have a totally separate question, which is just regarding dividend policy. Can you speak to it? I mean, historically, over the years, I feel like you guys have tried to maintain your dividend to add taxable net income,
componenttext: Okay, interesting. Okay. And say, I have a totally separate question, which is just regarding dividend policy. Can you speak to it? I mean, historically, over the years, I feel like you guys have tried to maintain your dividend to add taxable net income, essentially. But by the same token as your portfolio had seasoned and your leverage had declined relative to the size of the overall portfolio, your payout ratios have climbed. I think at the peak of the last cycle, you were probably paying out less than 50% of cash flow as a dividend. And today, we've got you in the low 80s or something like that. Can you speak to that at all? And are there any strategies that you can employ besides sort of maybe levering up where you would be able to sort of reduce that? And is that on your mind?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Jordan, if you -- let's go back to the -- kind of the middle of your question, start to where were we at the 2008, 2009 kind of the great recession and we were at 50% payout. Why were we that low?  Well, we had done the Shurgard merger in 2
componenttext:
:  
          Jordan, if you -- let's go back to the -- kind of the middle of your question, start to where were we at the 2008, 2009 kind of the great recession and we were at 50% payout. Why were we that low?  Well, we had done the Shurgard merger in 2006. And if you recall, that was about a $5.5 billion deal. The structure of that, even though it was all stock, has a taxable transaction, so -- which was very important to us. So we picked up a lot of tax basis in that transaction in one shot. In addition, a lot of the merger cost and option exercise cost and severance cost, we waited till the deal closed. And so we got a lot of tax benefits from that transaction in '06, '07, '08, which helped keep our -- build our -- our earnings were growing. Our payout wasn't changing. And so the spread between earnings and payout got very low, to your comment. As time has gone on, the portfolios continued to improve. We've delevered, and some of those tax benefits have burned off to where we're -- basically, our payout is still a taxable income. That strategy has not changed in 25 years. It's still a taxable income. But as the portfolio's grown, we're only able to retain $250 million, $300 million a year. So as the earnings base has grown, that has reduced our percentage of retained cash flow. The absolute number's about the same, but percentage-wise. And therefore, our payout ratio has gone up. John, you want to -- in terms of if we did leverage, would that help us, if it was positive leverage, it'd probably exacerbate the problem.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  And the other thing, Jordan, is we just recently increased our dividend. So we increased it to a level that we think will sustain us probably for another year. So right now, what you're seeing is that 80% that you threw out will probably dip down int
componenttext:
:  
And the other thing, Jordan, is we just recently increased our dividend. So we increased it to a level that we think will sustain us probably for another year. So right now, what you're seeing is that 80% that you threw out will probably dip down into the 70s. So it's not -- you're looking at, I think, for one quarter because we just bumped it this past quarter. But it will get back down in the 70s again. So you're looking at the front end of that dividend increase relative to the current earnings. What we did is projected out earnings for the next 12 months and came up with that dividend level. So I think you'll see it come back a little bit more in line, but it's not going back down. At 50%, I think we've probably -- we pretty much hit the wall in terms of, I think, what we can do to reduce taxable income. So I think that's what you're going to see our payout ratio before the foreseeable future.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Does that factor at all when you're underwriting an acquisition the ability to sort of utilize that depreciation and retain that cash flow? I mean, because on your base, it's obviously, pretty significant.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm just saying, is that a piece of the equation? As you look at portfolios and you look at M&A, are you looking at this potential free cash flow freeing up, this monstrous free cash flow that you get the tax benefit of.
componenttext: I'm just saying, is that a piece of the equation? As you look at portfolios and you look at M&A, are you looking at this potential free cash flow freeing up, this monstrous free cash flow that you get the tax benefit of.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes. Well, the -- let me go back to the Shurgard transaction. So the way that was structured is what are the underlying cash flows, what's the underlying real estate and how much real estate value are we giving up by issuing 20% of our stoc
componenttext:
:  
          Yes. Well, the -- let me go back to the Shurgard transaction. So the way that was structured is what are the underlying cash flows, what's the underlying real estate and how much real estate value are we giving up by issuing 20% of our stock, 25% of our stock in exchange for the Shurgard asset. So that was the way we structured the deal, the pricing we came up with the deal. We didn't factor in synergies and we didn't factor in the tax attributes. Those things were icing on the cake, and to take care of the things that we didn't know about in the transaction. So our underwriting on real estate, the way we think about it, what market, submarkets really goes to that question I answered earlier about our strategy of building presence and dominance in market, building and buying A and B locations. The tax side of it is not part of that underwriting analysis in terms of what we'll pay for something or our view on the quality of the real estate.
