headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I don't want to get hung up on 1 quarter, but when I look at the performance that you guys put up on same-store revenue, a 10 basis point deceleration from last quarter, not a big deal. But when I compare it relative to have your peers have reported, t
componenttext: So I don't want to get hung up on 1 quarter, but when I look at the performance that you guys put up on same-store revenue, a 10 basis point deceleration from last quarter, not a big deal. But when I compare it relative to have your peers have reported, the other guys were able to reaccelerate or continue acceleration this quarter. Just curious what your thoughts were on why your portfolio didn't reaccelerate.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, this is Ron. I thought we had an exceptionally good quarter. Comparing us to others is a little hard both because of geography mix as well as what people put in their same stores versus what we put in our same-stores. So it's a little apples and ban
componenttext: Okay, this is Ron. I thought we had an exceptionally good quarter. Comparing us to others is a little hard both because of geography mix as well as what people put in their same stores versus what we put in our same-stores. So it's a little apples and bananas.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you give a quick update what you're [indiscernible] 4 this quarter and just year-over-year?
componenttext: Okay. And can you give a quick update what you're [indiscernible] 4 this quarter and just year-over-year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll tell you what our moving rates were up by because that's more important than Street rates.  Street rates -- the moving rates were up about 5% year-over-year, 5.3% actually. Our move-ins were -- just to add a little bit more to that. Our move-in
componenttext: Well, I'll tell you what our moving rates were up by because that's more important than Street rates.  Street rates -- the moving rates were up about 5% year-over-year, 5.3% actually. Our move-ins were -- just to add a little bit more to that. Our move-ins were up about 1% with higher move-in rates by about 5.3%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see. I mean, it seems a little bit lower than last quarter's 8% number. Any reason why, particular reason why?
componenttext: I see. I mean, it seems a little bit lower than last quarter's 8% number. Any reason why, particular reason why?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last year, we also had less move-ins, too. So we had about 1% less move-ins with an 8% increase in move-in rates. I would say the second quarter was, by far, a very strong quarter for us. Third quarter is a great quarter, too, but not as strong as I think
componenttext: Last year, we also had less move-ins, too. So we had about 1% less move-ins with an 8% increase in move-in rates. I would say the second quarter was, by far, a very strong quarter for us. Third quarter is a great quarter, too, but not as strong as I think what we saw in the second quarter. The other thing that happened in the third quarter is we spent about 20% less in marketing costs. So we didn't spend nearly as much as we spent last year on both the Internet on search terms as well as on television. So that doesn't show up on the top line. It shows that in the expense line. But nonetheless, pretty happy that we got a 1% increase in move-ins, with about 5.3% increase in rate without doing nearly as much marketing as we did last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: During the quarter, it looks like only 2 property acquisitions closed, and you had a little larger pipeline at the end of last quarter. Is this just because those deals are C/O deals you had to close? Or is there any sort of delay in closing deals going o
componenttext: During the quarter, it looks like only 2 property acquisitions closed, and you had a little larger pipeline at the end of last quarter. Is this just because those deals are C/O deals you had to close? Or is there any sort of delay in closing deals going on?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, they weren't C/O deals. The challenge with them is they had debt assumptions, CMBS debt assumptions, which, if you've ever done one of that, that's like getting tooth expected. So it's taking a little longer to close. But I think we've got, yes, 10 or
componenttext: No, they weren't C/O deals. The challenge with them is they had debt assumptions, CMBS debt assumptions, which, if you've ever done one of that, that's like getting tooth expected. So it's taking a little longer to close. But I think we've got, yes, 10 or 11 C/O closed in Q4.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other thing. In terms of the debt issuance private placement euro-denominated, but going forward, would you guys also be looking to do a U.S. dollar-denominated issuance if you guys had a use for the proceeds?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other thing. In terms of the debt issuance private placement euro-denominated, but going forward, would you guys also be looking to do a U.S. dollar-denominated issuance if you guys had a use for the proceeds?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably, yes.
componenttext: Probably, yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Steve Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Steve Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask you, looking through the first 9 months, you've done an amazing job of keeping the total costs down, only up 1.3%, the cost of operating the properties. And as you look into next year, what are kind of the key areas where you might be
componenttext: I just wanted to ask you, looking through the first 9 months, you've done an amazing job of keeping the total costs down, only up 1.3%, the cost of operating the properties. And as you look into next year, what are kind of the key areas where you might be seeing, I guess, more pressure? I would imagine property tax is one of them, but are there any others that you see any particular upticks?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Smead. I think property taxes, they were up about 6.1% for the quarter on our same-store properties, 5.1% year-to-date. That would continue to be a challenge. John can elaborate on that. Payroll will probably be 2% to 3%. We've enjoyed for the last 2
componenttext: Yes, Smead. I think property taxes, they were up about 6.1% for the quarter on our same-store properties, 5.1% year-to-date. That would continue to be a challenge. John can elaborate on that. Payroll will probably be 2% to 3%. We've enjoyed for the last 2 or 3 years declining advertising and Internet costs because the portfolio has been full. We've been able to extend customer duration, and so we just have not needed to spend as much on promotion. I would be surprised if that number continues to decline in 2016. And then the other categories, I just assume kind of a general inflation rate. So I don't -- quarter-to-date, for the quarter, our advertising promotion was down 19% year-to-date. It's down 18%, and that's really contributed to the big decline or flatlining of expenses. And again, I wouldn't expect that to continue. John, any comments on property taxes?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, nothing particular. I mean, we're all seeing the property taxes are going up. Many, many municipalities are becoming more and more aggressive not only on the valuation at least with respect to our portfolio, reassessing the values. We do the
componenttext: Yes. I mean, nothing particular. I mean, we're all seeing the property taxes are going up. Many, many municipalities are becoming more and more aggressive not only on the valuation at least with respect to our portfolio, reassessing the values. We do the best we can to kind of push back on valuations, but I guess, tougher and tougher and they're more aggressive out there. So I expect that next year, we can probably, this year we're looking at about a 5% increase for the full fiscal year. Next year I wouldn't be surprised if that bumps up to about 6%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay. And could you just maybe -- you just mentioned length of stay or duration. What is that now? And sort of how is that changing? Or how has that changed over the course of the year?
componenttext: Great. Okay. And could you just maybe -- you just mentioned length of stay or duration. What is that now? And sort of how is that changing? Or how has that changed over the course of the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. For the quarter, we had 56.6% of our customers with us greater than a year. That is up from 55.8% at the same time last year. So 0.8% increase, absolute increase, in the percentage of customers greater than a year. To put that into perspective, in 2
componenttext: Sure. For the quarter, we had 56.6% of our customers with us greater than a year. That is up from 55.8% at the same time last year. So 0.8% increase, absolute increase, in the percentage of customers greater than a year. To put that into perspective, in 2012, that number was 54.5%. So if you could look at it over last 2 or 3 years, each quarter, quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year, we've been able to move the the length of stay up a percentage of customers greater than a year. That translates into this year versus last year, we've got 13,400 more customers greater than a year in the portfolio, a 2.2% improvement.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Smotrich with Jeremy. Hey, Ron, you've been at this, what, 20, 25-plus years? I'm pretty sure this was as good as you've ever seen it in the business. What's keeping you up at night? I mean, it looks like, at least for the time being, as we look
componenttext: It's Ross Smotrich with Jeremy. Hey, Ron, you've been at this, what, 20, 25-plus years? I'm pretty sure this was as good as you've ever seen it in the business. What's keeping you up at night? I mean, it looks like, at least for the time being, as we look ahead to 2016, it doesn't seem to be anything that's going to throw a wrench into the system. So other than the supply numbers picking up, is there anything that worries you about the ability to maintain pricing power?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things, Ross. New supply is coming, and I believe it will continue to accelerate for all the right, rational reasons. You can build far cheaper that you can buy. Operating fundamentals in the business are unbelievably good for a variety
componenttext: Well, a couple of things, Ross. New supply is coming, and I believe it will continue to accelerate for all the right, rational reasons. You can build far cheaper that you can buy. Operating fundamentals in the business are unbelievably good for a variety of reasons: full employment, job creation, the economy's doing well, low interest rates. So the fundamentals of the business are exceptional. You can capital to build. So new supply is coming, and at some point, that will start to impact people's pricing power, right? Simple supply and demand. As more supply comes in, that will impact pricing power. I don't see that being a big, negative headwind at least for another year, but it's coming. And then in terms of economy, I can't predict the economy, but the economy is being good. So things that hit the economy tend to be shocks, and then it disrupts the business environment and then you start to have enough uptick in unemployment and layoffs and all those things, which tend to not severely affect us but will slow growth down. So that's probably on the horizon. But I mean, the fundamentals of our business our great because of employment and historical last 4, 5 years, like a new supply.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a quick one on discounts. It seems like the gains from the lower discounting may be largely behind us at this point. Just wondering if you can give us an update on where they trend in 3Q relative to last year and just how you're viewing discoun
componenttext: I just had a quick one on discounts. It seems like the gains from the lower discounting may be largely behind us at this point. Just wondering if you can give us an update on where they trend in 3Q relative to last year and just how you're viewing discounting here going into the slower season.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeremy, this is John. We -- in terms of the number of tenants getting discounts during the third quarter, I think we were giving them to about 70% of the move-ins versus about, I think, about 73% or 75% last year. But the absolute dollars of this counts a
componenttext: Jeremy, this is John. We -- in terms of the number of tenants getting discounts during the third quarter, I think we were giving them to about 70% of the move-ins versus about, I think, about 73% or 75% last year. But the absolute dollars of this counts are actually up because our rental rates are higher than that -- than the percentage decrease and the absolute number. So we are getting less, but it's translating into more dollars because our rental rates are up. I think for the quarter, our accounting, just to give you some numbers, we gave away about $23 million of discounts. That's versus $22 million last year. So we're up about 5% there.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just going back to Europe. Can you just talk about any sort of additional opportunity there? A bunch of smaller players, clearly, they don't have the platform you guys have or many of the other U.S. players have. Just to just give us some sense of any inc
componenttext: Just going back to Europe. Can you just talk about any sort of additional opportunity there? A bunch of smaller players, clearly, they don't have the platform you guys have or many of the other U.S. players have. Just to just give us some sense of any incremental opportunities there you see.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's -- recall, there is only Western Europe now 1,600, 1,800 properties in all of Western Europe. I think 800 to 900 of them are in Great Britain, and all of those are outside of Landon. And we don't really want in terms of Great Britain, we real
componenttext: Yes. There's -- recall, there is only Western Europe now 1,600, 1,800 properties in all of Western Europe. I think 800 to 900 of them are in Great Britain, and all of those are outside of Landon. And we don't really want in terms of Great Britain, we really don't want to go outside of Landon. So a lot of those just don't come into our radar in terms of where we want to grow the portfolio. In several of the markets we have dominant share, Stockholm, Belgium, 70%, 80% share of the market. In terms of the rest of Europe, it's probably a couple hundred million of stuff to do, but not a lot. Give you some perspective. You take the city of Berlin, 3.5 million people, where we acquired 2 properties earlier this year, there are 15 self-storage properties in Berlin with 3.5 million people. So you have markets like that where, clearly, the opportunity is to develop versus acquire because there is really not much to acquire. So that's the ramping up our development program in Europe. We were fortunate to get these 2 acquisitions that may be, like I said, EUR 100 million or EUR 150 million more. But really, the growth in Europe is going to come from development for us.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's you're looking to maybe develop some additional assets there?
componenttext: So that's you're looking to maybe develop some additional assets there?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've got -- we opened 1 in Landon this quarter, and we've got 2 more coming on underground in the next 6 months. We've hired a person to help us in Germany and, in particular, Berlin. And so you should expect some development activity in that market
componenttext: Yes. We've got -- we opened 1 in Landon this quarter, and we've got 2 more coming on underground in the next 6 months. We've hired a person to help us in Germany and, in particular, Berlin. And so you should expect some development activity in that market next year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your sense of what the heels are over there versus here in the U.S.
componenttext: Your sense of what the heels are over there versus here in the U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I haven't seen anything on paper yet, but my guess is they'll be close to the U.S.
componenttext: I haven't seen anything on paper yet, but my guess is they'll be close to the U.S.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up to Jeremy's question. You ran through the discounting in the quarter, but I think you've previously talked about that as sort of the overall customer acquisition cost. And I was just wondering if you could share with us where that cost is
componenttext: Just a follow-up to Jeremy's question. You ran through the discounting in the quarter, but I think you've previously talked about that as sort of the overall customer acquisition cost. And I was just wondering if you could share with us where that cost is today and how that's trended over the last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So for the quarter, Todd, our marketing costs were down $1 million. Our discounts were up $800,000. So net-net, we were kind of flat on promotional costs. Move-ins were up about 1% [ph] of 2,000, as John said. So our cost to acquire a customer went
componenttext: Sure. So for the quarter, Todd, our marketing costs were down $1 million. Our discounts were up $800,000. So net-net, we were kind of flat on promotional costs. Move-ins were up about 1% [ph] of 2,000, as John said. So our cost to acquire a customer went down $1 from 126 to 125. The move-in rate was up 5% or $7. The move-ins fees were up $1. So net-net, for each customer, we made $35 upon move-ins versus 26 last year. So it's a 35% improvement in our customer acquisition costs for the quarter. Year-to-date, numbers are somewhat comparable. We have a 31% improvement in customer acquisition cost from 26 to 34 again due to lower spend, greater volume, higher rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is 35 -- is that a peak for the portfolio?
componenttext: Is 35 -- is that a peak for the portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of profitability of move-in?
componenttext: In terms of profitability of move-in?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry, is that the highest number? Yes, the most profitable quarter that you've seen.
componenttext: Sorry, is that the highest number? Yes, the most profitable quarter that you've seen.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Since we've been tracking this? Yes. Yes. Our overall promotional marketing costs, to kind of put in different light for you, 2011, we spent 9.2% of revenues on promotional discounts and marketing costs. And year-to-date, we're at 5.7%.
componenttext: Since we've been tracking this? Yes. Yes. Our overall promotional marketing costs, to kind of put in different light for you, 2011, we spent 9.2% of revenues on promotional discounts and marketing costs. And year-to-date, we're at 5.7%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a question on development. It sounds like the C/O portfolios within the REIT portfolios are kind of growing rather quickly here, and developers are bringing sites to the market. You're talking about new supply accelerat
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a question on development. It sounds like the C/O portfolios within the REIT portfolios are kind of growing rather quickly here, and developers are bringing sites to the market. You're talking about new supply accelerating. What's happening to land prices? And is the competition for development impacting your ability to start new projects? Is the pipeline potentially going to send out a little bit?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It hasn't so far, but my guess, my expectation is that it will change as development is ramped up and more people start to do it. But that really hasn't been an impediment for us. The thing that we are seeing is an uptick in construction costs. And it's h
componenttext: It hasn't so far, but my guess, my expectation is that it will change as development is ramped up and more people start to do it. But that really hasn't been an impediment for us. The thing that we are seeing is an uptick in construction costs. And it's harder in some markets to get contractors available to perform the construction. Guys are building apartments and hotels and retail. And so the construction business is pretty good now. So we've seen one more challenge on the labor contractor side and then an uptick in material costs. Again, not big enough to slow us down, but we have seen that versus 2 years ago when we started.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Dave Bragg with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Dave Bragg with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: G&A saw another pretty large increase again this quarter. We assume that it's again driven by legal costs. Can you talk about when we should expect to receive more clarity on the nature of these costs?
componenttext: G&A saw another pretty large increase again this quarter. We assume that it's again driven by legal costs. Can you talk about when we should expect to receive more clarity on the nature of these costs?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Was there legal fees? And in this quarter, we had -- we booked a $3.5 million reserve for a proposed settlement. And David, if you recall in our 10-Q, we have -- we break out in a fair amount of granularity the components of G&A.
componenttext: Was there legal fees? And in this quarter, we had -- we booked a $3.5 million reserve for a proposed settlement. And David, if you recall in our 10-Q, we have -- we break out in a fair amount of granularity the components of G&A.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've seen that. We look forward to it this quarter. And as far as you can see, the outlook for '16, legal expenses relative 2015, does it look like this will subside?
componenttext: Yes, we've seen that. We look forward to it this quarter. And as far as you can see, the outlook for '16, legal expenses relative 2015, does it look like this will subside?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I hope so.
componenttext: I hope so.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, good. Second question, although you've been pretty clear in recent quarters that you continue to pursue debt options, how about a commercial paper program, which a couple other very large REITs have pursued, is that on your radar screen?
componenttext: All right, good. Second question, although you've been pretty clear in recent quarters that you continue to pursue debt options, how about a commercial paper program, which a couple other very large REITs have pursued, is that on your radar screen?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. It's not even thinking that way.
componenttext: No. It's not even thinking that way.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. Last question is on property taxes. You talked about an outlook there. Relative to prior cycles, what's your view on the extent to which assessments are below market? And is there any -- outside of California, is there any big variability?
componenttext: Okay. Okay. Last question is on property taxes. You talked about an outlook there. Relative to prior cycles, what's your view on the extent to which assessments are below market? And is there any -- outside of California, is there any big variability?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- this is John, David. I think California is probably, as you pointed out, in spite -- because of [indiscernible] 13 [ph] is probably the biggest variable. And it was other states, depending on what you think market is and what assessors think ma
componenttext: I think -- this is John, David. I think California is probably, as you pointed out, in spite -- because of [indiscernible] 13 [ph] is probably the biggest variable. And it was other states, depending on what you think market is and what assessors think market is. I think most of our properties are either accessed each year or every other year at the worse. So they're probably, for the most part, fairly close to market. I'm guessing at that. I don't know because, again, I don't know what the assessors are looking at.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Mueller with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Mueller with JP Morgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going to development for a second. I guess if you put aside a project like Gerard or something, can you talk about what you're seeing in terms of the time to lease up new developments there compared to underwriting? And then, I guess, for expansion, is th
componenttext: Going to development for a second. I guess if you put aside a project like Gerard or something, can you talk about what you're seeing in terms of the time to lease up new developments there compared to underwriting? And then, I guess, for expansion, is that really going to be a function of size? So I guess just on the new development side, what you're seeing?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mike, the new developments are leasing up much faster than we underwrite. Now the part of that's attributable to the fact that we're opening them with the lower rates than we're underwriting and probably a few more discounts. But we opened a property
componenttext: Yes. Mike, the new developments are leasing up much faster than we underwrite. Now the part of that's attributable to the fact that we're opening them with the lower rates than we're underwriting and probably a few more discounts. But we opened a property here in Glendale in May, 2,000 units. It's about 1.5 miles here from corporate headquarters, and it's already 72% occupied. So -- which is phenomenal. I mean, we underwrote it for 3-, 3.5-year fill-up. And that one's actually pretty close in terms of rates that we underwrote. That's filling up rates pretty closely that we underwrote. In general, for development, depending on the size of the property, we underwrite a 3- to 4-year fill-up and a reserve in terms of the cost to carry that property until it stabilizes. So so far, knock on wood, developments are filling up much faster than anticipated.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then I guess for the projects where you really cut the rent and fill it up, I mean, do you try -- can you bring everybody to market the year after that or close to it? Or do you have to staggered? I mean, what's the dynamic there?
componenttext: Got it. And then I guess for the projects where you really cut the rent and fill it up, I mean, do you try -- can you bring everybody to market the year after that or close to it? Or do you have to staggered? I mean, what's the dynamic there?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It'll take a couple of years to -- it depends on how far below "market" we brought them in at. So it'll take a couple of years of rent, rental rate increases to get them close to market. And then once the property stabilizes, we'll bring the rents closer
componenttext: It'll take a couple of years to -- it depends on how far below "market" we brought them in at. So it'll take a couple of years of rent, rental rate increases to get them close to market. And then once the property stabilizes, we'll bring the rents closer to market. And so it'll take a couple of years of rent roll-up before to get kind of the targeted or underwritten rental rate in place rents.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a question on Glendale, which you successfully anticipated. Maybe I'll just ask one more on the balance sheet. You mentioned not wanting to do commercial paper. But would the preference be for tenure debt or maybe pushing out to 30 years? What's the
componenttext: I had a question on Glendale, which you successfully anticipated. Maybe I'll just ask one more on the balance sheet. You mentioned not wanting to do commercial paper. But would the preference be for tenure debt or maybe pushing out to 30 years? What's the mindset on the debt market?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right now, yes, we could do -- people look at 7-, 10-, 12-, 15-, 30-year debt. So right now, we just -- when we go out there and issue debt again, we'll probably look at how that's going to -- we want to properly tranche the debt so that we feel comfortab
componenttext: Right now, yes, we could do -- people look at 7-, 10-, 12-, 15-, 30-year debt. So right now, we just -- when we go out there and issue debt again, we'll probably look at how that's going to -- we want to properly tranche the debt so that we feel comfortable with future bullet maturities. So I think right now for us, we're not ready to do another one, but when we do, we will look at various maturity dates.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the acquisitions. The 2 in Colorado, you have a few teed up to close. Looks like in the near term, California, Florida and Texas. Can you talk about the difference in cap rates you're seeing, if there is any, really on a stabilized basis?
componenttext: Just looking at the acquisitions. The 2 in Colorado, you have a few teed up to close. Looks like in the near term, California, Florida and Texas. Can you talk about the difference in cap rates you're seeing, if there is any, really on a stabilized basis?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Todd, I don't think there's a material difference. For the most part, stuff is trading at trailing 4 to 5 yields on previous owner's NOI. And that seems kind of the market or the market expectation. The thing that we've given -- that we pay a lot of atten
componenttext: Todd, I don't think there's a material difference. For the most part, stuff is trading at trailing 4 to 5 yields on previous owner's NOI. And that seems kind of the market or the market expectation. The thing that we've given -- that we pay a lot of attention to it is what is replacement cost and asset locations so what we think we can do in terms of rental rates, and then how much does this property cost versus what is the cost to build. So out of those 11 properties, 800,000 square feet, just over 800,000 square feet, you have about $132 a foot, which is kind of within plus minus 5%, 10% of what we think we can build the properties for.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And what types of -- any details on the MSAs you're buying in? Are these the top 25? And what's your appetite to kind of go within the top 50?
componenttext: And what types of -- any details on the MSAs you're buying in? Are these the top 25? And what's your appetite to kind of go within the top 50?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're finding the top 50. These particular properties fill in our portfolio nicely, both in terms of, I think, the Florida [ph] ones are primarily in Orlando, and they fill in our Orlando franchise nicely as well as the stuff in Dallas and Houston. So it'
componenttext: We're finding the top 50. These particular properties fill in our portfolio nicely, both in terms of, I think, the Florida [ph] ones are primarily in Orlando, and they fill in our Orlando franchise nicely as well as the stuff in Dallas and Houston. So it's really -- if you think of a market like Dallas or Houston our Orlando where we have anywhere between 50 and 100, 120 properties, we're really trying to do acquisitions that fill in the franchise, covers markets where maybe we don't necessarily have product but would like to have product.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then finally if you could just give or shed some light on how your underwriting assumptions, particularly for the Glendale properties. You said it's leasing up at 72% occupied. How does that relate to what your underwriting yield was and relati
componenttext: Great. And then finally if you could just give or shed some light on how your underwriting assumptions, particularly for the Glendale properties. You said it's leasing up at 72% occupied. How does that relate to what your underwriting yield was and relative to how quickly you can lease it up?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, 5 months into it, we would have underwritten about 20%, 24% occupancy, so it's 72%. So even though the rates may be slightly low, the cash we're getting and the net cash flow properties already breaking even generating a profit. So we would have und
componenttext: Well, 5 months into it, we would have underwritten about 20%, 24% occupancy, so it's 72%. So even though the rates may be slightly low, the cash we're getting and the net cash flow properties already breaking even generating a profit. So we would have underwritten that and not make a profit for 6 to 9 months. So we're already net positive cash. It'll take a couple of years to -- when it stabilizes, to really stop and saying what is the cash-on-cash return and how much extra money do we make by filling up faster versus taking a more traditional approach of starting rates higher and filling it up slower. I'd also say that property is rather iconic, and there's a lot of great things going on in Glendale. So the market was undersupplied. And so there's another aspect of building the right product in the right submarket, and certainly, the property fits the bill there. Did that answer your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tina with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tina with Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A trend we're seeing in apartments currently a smaller MSAs are experiencing stronger rent growth and the larger markets. I was curious if you're seeing that in storage as well. Or does kind of rates and demand continued to be primarily driven by submarke
componenttext: A trend we're seeing in apartments currently a smaller MSAs are experiencing stronger rent growth and the larger markets. I was curious if you're seeing that in storage as well. Or does kind of rates and demand continued to be primarily driven by submarket density?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let's see, I'm looking here at the revenue growth for our -- most of our markets.  our top revenue grower for the quarter was Portland 15.7, followed by Orlando at 13.5, Sacramento at 13.8. Nashville was 12.1. Dallas was 11.9. Houston was 11. Does t
componenttext: Well, let's see, I'm looking here at the revenue growth for our -- most of our markets.  our top revenue grower for the quarter was Portland 15.7, followed by Orlando at 13.5, Sacramento at 13.8. Nashville was 12.1. Dallas was 11.9. Houston was 11. Does that give you a sense of things. The flip side as Philadelphia, 4.3, DC at 3.2, Chicago at 3.2.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Ross again. Is there any thought of potentially using some equity funding here, given the in the stock this year? How are you taking about cost of capital on the equity side [indiscernible]?
componenttext: It's Ross again. Is there any thought of potentially using some equity funding here, given the in the stock this year? How are you taking about cost of capital on the equity side [indiscernible]?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Ross, you're certainly like the stock price. It certainly reflects the great fundamental trends of our business. But one of the things you ask yourself is, does it really make sense to issue equity when we have so -- such an unlevered balance sheet?
componenttext: Well, Ross, you're certainly like the stock price. It certainly reflects the great fundamental trends of our business. But one of the things you ask yourself is, does it really make sense to issue equity when we have so -- such an unlevered balance sheet? And we can do -- we did the euro deal at 2.7 or 2.17. And we could probably do a 10-year deal at sub-4%, does it really makes sense to go issue equity? John, do you have any other further comments on that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, yes, not ask yourself, what's the cost of capital of issuing common stock? I mean, there's growth. I mean, I'm sure you're just looking at a cap rate, whatever you think it is trading at. For example, say you're seeing it's floor cap rates. Bu
componenttext: No. I mean, yes, not ask yourself, what's the cost of capital of issuing common stock? I mean, there's growth. I mean, I'm sure you're just looking at a cap rate, whatever you think it is trading at. For example, say you're seeing it's floor cap rates. But if we'll probably grow somewhat in the neighborhood of 3.5%, 4% on unlevered basis, which in my mind, brings cost of capital, issuing comments in the neighborhood of, call it, 6% to 7%, which again, when you combine that with the delevered balance sheet, I think our first choice right now is to lever up the balance sheet with debt and fund our acquisitions and development programs with that method first going forward. It's not to say that we won't issue equity. If for the right transaction, the transaction came along, we'd certainly consider issuing equity.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there any part of you that's ever thought about actually bringing the leverage of the company up closer to, I would say, the REIT average, if you will? So go out into a multibillion debt issuance and just do a special dividend and just recapitalize the
componenttext: Is there any part of you that's ever thought about actually bringing the leverage of the company up closer to, I would say, the REIT average, if you will? So go out into a multibillion debt issuance and just do a special dividend and just recapitalize the company. Is there any thought to that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not at this time.
componenttext: Not at this time.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the  last follow-up I had. So I drive by a number of your facilities quite often. Some of them look beautiful, spectacular, new, shiny. And some of them look 30-plus years old. Some of them have toll-free number on them. Some of them have t
componenttext: Okay. And then the  last follow-up I had. So I drive by a number of your facilities quite often. Some of them look beautiful, spectacular, new, shiny. And some of them look 30-plus years old. Some of them have toll-free number on them. Some of them have the Internet site on them. I guess, maybe can you talk a little bit about branding and consistency of branding? And how important do you think that is going forward, right? When I drive by a McDonalds, they're usually the same. When I drive by a Public Storage, increasingly, they're not. Maybe talk a little bit about how much of an issue that is or is not.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, given our current occupancies, I would say it's not too much of an impediment. The key for the branding there are the orange doors and the name Public Storage. And that is so dominant and so powerful, I mean, it's just unbelievable. We can talk for
componenttext: Well, given our current occupancies, I would say it's not too much of an impediment. The key for the branding there are the orange doors and the name Public Storage. And that is so dominant and so powerful, I mean, it's just unbelievable. We can talk for an hour about what it does for us on the Internet, customer awareness, et cetera, et cetera. The point you raised in terms of dichotomy of our, I'll call it, property image, is certainly true. And one of the things that we've been doing for several years is redeveloping properties. And it's a little harder than you think because in many of those kind of infill locations where you're probably driving by, self-storage has been zoned out. And we can't get the city to even reconsider redeveloping the property because they've just assumed it wasn't there. You're down in Florida, so the property down there in Ventura that we redeveloped took us 4 years to get that done. So while we'd like to go through and change up the image of the properties and standardize it, it's a lot more challenging than on the surface. And combined with there's a dichotomy in the portfolio because a lot of it's been acquired from other people that built it to different standards or different specs. And so it's going to look different. And also -- that's also due to -- attributable to different zoning regulations. So even some of the new stuff that we build, I think we've got 1 property where we can't have any orange on it. Not our choice, but that's the zoning regulations.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the our next question comes from the line of Andrew Rosivach from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: I think the our next question comes from the line of Andrew Rosivach from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A prior question, did I hear -- I just want to make sure I heard this correctly that, obviously, your G&A has been elevated, as you mentioned, because of the Q because of legal expenses, but that the primary case associated with those legal expenses has n
componenttext: A prior question, did I hear -- I just want to make sure I heard this correctly that, obviously, your G&A has been elevated, as you mentioned, because of the Q because of legal expenses, but that the primary case associated with those legal expenses has now been settled?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's a reserve that we made in Q3 for about $3.5 million, and it's a tentative settlement. We have other ongoing litigation. So...
